NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the CARIBOO INDIAN RES. SCHOOL School for the Quarter ended March 31st 1942

Principal

Dated March 31st 1942

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

The Honorable T. M. Daly
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs

Honorable Sir,

I humbly beg to state that two years ago I undertook to carry on an industrial school for the Indians of William's Lake Agency at the Roman Catholic Mission William's Lake, the Federal Government granting an annual capitation of $150.00 for each of fifty pupils and I devoting to said purpose the actual school buildings of the Mission, consisting in two separate houses, one for the boys and the other for the girls.

There are today at the said Industrial School 24 Indian Boys and 18 Indian girls.

But it has happened that the building for the girls needed be repaired and enlarged and I had to expend last year four thousand dollars in said building. And now I receive a letter from the Revd. Father Lepage, Principal of the Industrial School, stating that the school-house for the Boys is becoming old and is also too small, so new building is required. It will necessitate a considerable outlay which is entirely above my means.

I humbly beg that the Dominion come graciously to my assistance.
in granting once for all the sum of five thousand dollars and so enable me to erect said new construction.

Should such grant appear too large, I would humbly bring to your notice that I have already expended four thousand dollars in repairing and enlarging the Girls' building, I had to make a big outlay in providing beds and beddings and other furnitures for the two Departments, and I have still to lay out a good amount of cash in erecting the necessary workshops to train the boys in blacksmithing, carpentering, shoe and harness-making, besides the buying of the tools and various implements for such trades.

I feel confident that you will take my demand in due consideration and grant it.

I have the honor to be

Dear and honorable Sir,

your humble servant

Paul Durieu, O.M.I.

To the Hon. J.M. Daly

Honorable Sir,

I regret very much to have been obliged to leave Ottawa without having the honor to meet you; but I thought it best to write my request, so that you might take it into consideration at your convenience. In the meantime, I must apologize for taking such liberty.

I came from British Columbia, at the request of His Lordship, Rt. Bishop Macdonald, to ask you, Honorable Sir, to give your kind attention, first to Williams Lake Industrial School, and next St. Mary's Mission School (the latter in my charge) both for the exclusive education of Indian children.

I have remitted to your private Secretary, a letter from the Bishop, explaining what is needed at Williams Lake. Last summer, at the time of your official visit to British Columbia, I had the honor to meet you, Honorable Sir. I then spoke to you about the insufficiency of my school at St. Mary's Mission, for our Indians (Catholics) of the Fraser River Tribe.

We have obtained from your kindness, an allocation of $2 per capita per annum, for 75 pupils. Needless to state that we had, under the able Mr. Denney, obtained a part of your said allocation, that is $100.00 for 75 pupils. I am glad to say that the Indians wish more earnestly for, and understand better the advantages of education. And consequently, Indian children benefit far more by what they learn in school.
In conclusion of all this, I apply for more, "that is to raise the number of our pupils to one hundred at the rate of $60.00 per Capita per annum," and that to commence 1st July 1844.

Considering the great needs of our Fraser River Indians, improving their condition, the application in giving satisfaction to those vested with power over them; consider the large number of children in age to go to school; I hope that you will not find their request unreasonable and you will be able to correspond with their just desire.

Hoping to hear from you,

I remain, your humble servant,

P.M.O. Cornelius O.M.I.

Sir,

On the 29th May last, about 5 o'clock P.M. at the St. Joseph's Industrial School, William's Lake, the water closets were discovered in a blaze; the fire alarm was rung, all the men, boys and girls with their buckets came up, they worked hard, but all they could do was to prevent the fire from spreading. Finding the water closet was the wood shed and near the harness shop, they had to be sacrificed. We had scarcely time to save anything; in less than a half hour, the whole shop was a mass of flame.

According to the statement read us and signed by the teacher, instructor, the loss is as follows:

Clothing (coats, blankets, handkerchiefs) is $125.00; besides, the instructor lost his gold watch $15.00; we lost our letters $3.00, our weight $30.00, our clock $6.00, and drapes $10.00. So here, so far, these articles were thrown away under the wood shed near the water closets. Total $1006.65.

Bearing in mind, providence and also confident that the Department will be coming to my help, I took immediate steps to replace what had been consumed by the fire. In order to comply with the wishes of the Department, who complained was not taking an except opportunity, I now put up a new building 30x40, two stories; on the ground floor will be the wood shop 20x40, and the office 10x10; on the second floor the instructor will have his lodgings and ladies' rooms, and the store room, his wood although the building is not quite finished yet to the present date, there is still the sum of $1006.65, which makes a total of losses together $2006.65.

I hope the Department will meet me halfway and grant a loan of $1000.00 to help me out of my difficulties.

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt through Indian Agent, Isaac Ogden, of your answer to my request dated Jan. 14th last, of a grant to help paying off a debt incurred through the necessary installation of furnaces and toilets for the pupils of this school.

This your answer is a simple refusal of all financial help. With all due respect I must say that I am very painfully surprised and with me the members of my staff. We trusted too much to the Department's sense of justice and equity as well as to its solicitude for the welfare of all Indian children in all the schools.

But as nothing in your letter indicates that this answer is final and as on the other hand I might not have sufficiently well explained the case I beg leave to again renew my request. I shall be pleased to give all and every explanation that the Department might need in order to adequately judge our case on its merits.

In my letter dat. Jan. 14th, I think, I have sufficiently well explained the absolute necessity there was for changing from small box stoves to furnaces. As this letter may not be on file any more, for convenience sake I enclose herewith another copy of it. On its perusal you will notice that I mention also as an important reason for the change: reducing to a minimum the danger of fire. First, we have reduced the number of chimneys to be watched from nine to two. Then without furnaces it is impossible to keep the water from freezing over night with the best possible care as has been
demonstrated again and again. Because we tried to follow the Department's rule: have pails filled with water always ready—we have lost them nearly all through frost in one night splitting them. But now, with a little more improvement to the water works we can have a stream of water in any story of every building should fire break out there.

Another very necessary point that the furnaces have allowed us to improve is: sanitation and sanitary precautions. We have new toilets and bathtubs in the boys' and girls' department. We could not think of these before putting in the furnaces.

It may be objected that we did all this without first asking the Department's approval and submitting plans. I beg to answer that I had been told that the Department could not give financial assistance before knowing that the undertaking would be a success. I could not possibly give this assurance without first trying. But we were so confident in the final success that we made a loan in the hope that the Department would come to our help in an improvement so very necessary and so very successful just as it has given financial support to other schools in undertakings not less necessary than this one. In my letter of Jan. 14th last I wrote: "Since a little over two months the furnaces have been burning practically day and night; the thermometer has registered already 23 below zero, but the children say: it is always warm in our school." I should think such a test is quite sufficient to prove the complete success of the work.

In further thinking of the possible motives the Department might have had in turning down my request it has come to my mind that perhaps the XXXX Department does not consider the results of this school sufficient to warrant the expenditure. I do not know in what this school might be (if it
William's Lake Industrial School

is at all) inferior to such as have received special grants now and then. But I know that the inspector of Indian schools, A.R. Green, has always pronounced himself pleased with what we do and the way we do it. His reports in the blue books speak for themselves. I therefore fail to see why our efforts and our work should not meet with the same appreciation and encouragement as do other schools. During these nine years that I have been at the head of this institution we have received, as extraordinary grant, only twenty new school desks for the girls' department; total cost was not to exceed $122.10 This, of course, was not sufficient to pay for all, transportation costs included.

I cannot well conclude without transcribing here from my yearly report what is said there of the pupils' health. "Under this heading (HEALTH AND SANITATION) I have been happy to say since a number of years that the children of this school always enjoy excellent health. Indeed, our inspector of schools, Mr. A.R. Green, in 1906 already declared that in no other school he found the children as healthy as here. (Cf. Blue Book, year 1906, p. 488). This good record has been kept up again as we have no contagious disease, no serious case of any kind, no death to deplore. Not surprising then to hear Indians here saying when presenting their offspring for admittance: "I'm afraid he'll die if I keep him." Hence the Department ought to feel relieved in knowing that any help extended to this institution produces more than a transitory benefit.

In order to still better explain the merits of our case I cannot pass over the fact that the school keeps on its own charge seventeen pupils above the allowed number (50). This number will be still more increased next July if I am able to purchase more beds.
Again it must be borne in mind that we are 135 miles from the nearest railway point and that goods are moved slowly at great expense by teams.

On account of all these reasons I pray the Department with all due respect to reconsider its answer and to give us the necessary help. I shall be pleased to give all and every explanation on any point you might call for.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

your obedient servant,

H. Boening

Principal.
Sir:

I have the honor to submit to your earnest and kind consideration my humble request for a special grant as help in the payment for improvements that I was obliged to make in the heating apparatus and the sanitary condition of this school. These improvements have taken place principally in the girls' department. In the past years ordinary box stoves were the only means of heating at this institution. But in such a severe climate these could never give satisfaction. Besides, what a great and continual danger of fire, not mentioning the trouble in cleaning chimneys at least once a month and the cost in fuel and repairs. In the girls' school alone sixteen stoves were sometimes burning at the same time. So we decided to make a test. In the fall of '08 we put up in the boys' department a hot air McGlary furnace No. 316. The test was a severe one as the thermometer last winter registered as much as 54 below zero. Without being very comfortable in such unheard off cold the boys, however, found themselves in warmer quarters than the girls. Impossible for the latter to work in the schoolroom or sewing-room. We decided then to do away with the stoves in the girls' department also and put in two hot air furnaces. But much excavating had first to be done as there was no basement. I am happy here to seize this occasion to bring to your knowledge with what extraordinary good will and zeal both boys and girls helped in this work. During the months of August, September and October a basement was made nearly the whole length of the girls' school. The exact measurements are: 110 x 18 x 7 ft. No other tools but picks and
shovels and buckets were used. Then we put in two hot air McClary furnaces No. 417, one with sixteen and the other with fifteen pipes. This work, too, was done by the principal with the help of the boys. We are all very pleased with the results. Since a little over two months the furnaces have been burning practically day and night; the thermometer has registered already 22 below zero but the children say: it is always warm in our school.

With the furnaces we have now also the great advantage of a never failing supply of fresh water without the fear of frost.

Then these two very valuable improvements have allowed us to make a third one: up-to-date toilet-rooms in boys' and girls' department.

All these very necessary improvements, XXXXXXXXXX, of course, could not be paid for out of the per capita grant as this does hardly cover the running expenses of this school, situated 135 miles from the nearest railway station with 67 pupils at present. As may be seen by the enclosed receipts we have paid $600.00 for the two furnaces complete and $450.50 for sanitary improvements. These figures do not include transportation and installation costs. I trust therefore to the sense of justice and generosity as well as to the solicitude of the Department for the advancement of the Indians and hope to receive a substantial grant as a help in paying off this debt that, as I have shown above, was very necessary.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
your obedient servant,

H. Boening.

"You are authorized to build new chimneys and foundations under school for two hot-air furnaces Cariboo Indian Industrial School by day labor or by competent Contractor on a proven cost plus a ten percent basis. (Signed) A. F. MacKenzie."

On receipt of this telegram I sent a copy of it to the Principal of the school and I visited the school soon after and found that the Principal was in Vancouver looking over similar buildings to the Cariboo School and getting advice as to what was required in the furnace line. He has since let the contract to construct the chimneys and foundations to a contractor after getting figures from other contractors, a copy of which I enclose herewith.

Dear Mr. Scott:

We have never to my knowledge, certainly not in recent years, applied to the Department for any extra aid to maintain our Indian School in the Cariboo. I consider it my duty to do so now.

The Cariboo School was established in 1867. The enclosed photo shows the relative positions of the main buildings as follows:
1- Boys' School
2- Dining Rooms, Kitchens, Laundry, Bakery and Electric Plant.
3- Girls' School.
4- Barn etc.

The Boys' and Girls' Schools are a full block apart. Needless to say we have during the past sixty-five years spent much money on the Cariboo School; Repairs and improvements are constantly being made. In 1919 we installed a Delco Electric Lighting Plant at a cost of $2,200.00. In 1920 we spent $2,000.00 on a new sewer system, and about five years ago about $2,000.00 on a laundry and bakery.

Other repairs and improvements are now urgently needed, and to these I now particularly wish to draw your attention.

A. Two new hot-air furnaces.

B. Six brick chimneys, at present we merely have stove pipes which are a constant menace to the safety of the buildings.

C. A barn for the cattle. There is a small barn for the horses but none for the milch cows. In Winter and Summer the cows are milked in the open. Winters in the Cariboo are very severe, and as a consequence the cows yield practically no milk or butter for six months in the year.
D.C.S.

The Girls' School should have foundations. In Spring and the early Summer the basement is flooded making it impossible to heat the furnace.

Lastly the water system is defective. Water for the School is brought from a lake a mile and a half away. What is required is a dam at the intake to enclose a greater body of water and to give greater pressure. Some days there is not enough water for the laundry, and when the laundry is being operated, there is an insufficient supply of water for the domestic purposes or for the barn and dairy. Probably $500.00 would be needed for the erection of a suitable dam.

If the above improvements were made we should be able to carry on for a number of years. We have not the funds to make the improvements ourselves.

You may wonder how we have succeeded in doing so much during the past few years. Allow me to explain; It was due to the high price we received for our cattle during the war. Then again we formerly had a ready market for our surplus hay, but since the construction of the P.G.E. Railway teamsters have deserted the Cariboo.

Yours respectfully,

J. Welch. O.M.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 26th September in which you inform me that the Reverend Principal of the Cariboo Industrial School had requested the Department to reimburse him to the extent of $450.00 to replace the cost of two chimneys in the girls' building following installation of two furnaces early this year.

In reply to your inquiry as to why it was necessary to tear down the two new chimneys authorized in August, 1923, and replace them, I beg to say that the explanation of this is that the two chimneys which were authorized in August, 1923, were erected for the two old furnaces in the school at that time though the management had been promised two new furnaces. Before the new furnaces were purchased I sent me it was deemed expedient to have a heating expert sent to the school to see just what was required and in Mr. Crane's report he made mention of the two new chimneys which had recently been erected but stated that they were not of sufficient area to accommodate the new furnaces, the old ones only having an area of 64 square inches (6" square) each whereas the new flues would require to be 15" X 20" inside measurement. Evidently it was a mistake on the part of the management of the school to build any chimneys at all until they had ascertained the dimensions required for the new furnaces which had been promised, but I am inclined to think they did the best they could under the circumstances and that the Department should take a favorable view of the case and reimburse the Principal for his outlay.

The Principal tells me that he also had to go to the expense of $92.86 for some further smoke pipes which were sent to the school afterwards, but possibly he has rendered an account for this already.

REPORT ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY.

SCHOOL - S. WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY. SUPERINTENDENT:

In company with the Principal, Rev. Father Mailiard and the Agent, Mr. MacLeod, I thoroughly inspected this Institution. I find things on a whole most satisfactory, and everything is kept very neat and clean. However, there are not enough quarters for the boys, being only four, and quite away to be used. This is most unsanitary. I should suggest a supply of rope ladders and hooks under the windows, or a canvas chute in each dormitory.

The washing up arrangements in the kitchen to say the least of it, are ridiculous. There being only one sink for the boys' use at school. I consider the sister in charge took no notice on strike. I thoroughly recommend this as justified, if only on humanitarian grounds. During my visit, work was being done in replacing the foundations of the girls' wing on stone and cement foundations.

FARM: The grounds appear to be very well farmed, but there is no dairy farm, and one should be erected, as the milk supply is most necessary for the well being and health of the children.

GENERAL: Altogether, the Principal, Father Mailiard is to be congratulated on the excellent condition of the school and grounds. I am of the opinion, however, that more attention should be required in the practical training of the children, apart from actual chores. The school was practically full during my visit, and I mention this to draw attention to the fact that so many of the children in this agency are not getting any education whatever. This particularly applies to the children in the Okanagan Valley, Anahams, Riske Creek, Neskonlith and others, and something will have to be done in the near future to rectify this.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) C. S. Freeman,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Father Welch and Rev. Father Millard, the authorities of the Roman Catholic Church, at the school and they informed him that they wished to have a barn similar to those which the Department built at the Kamloops and Lillooet Schools, also a refrigerator plant similar to that at Kamloops. Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just paid a visit to the Cariboo Industrial School, and am pleased to say that the institution in all departments is progressing most favourably.

Mr. McLeod the Agent happened to be there at the same time, and agreed with me that the cow barn and refrigerator should be erected without further delay. In this connection he has no doubt written you.

Last year you were good enough to authorize two new furnaces and a stone foundation for the girls' school. These improvements were much appreciated last winter. Though the weather was severe the children and Sisters for the first time suffered no discomfort.

I would now respectfully ask you to confer on us a similar favor in the building occupied by the Fathers and Brothers. The foundations are crumbling, and the furnace which has done duty for twenty years is nearly worn out and should be replaced immediately by another one at least a size larger.

Mr. R.A. Leonard who gave us entire satisfaction a year ago, has submitted to us an estimate and is prepared to put in a new stone foundation for $525.00. A certain amount of excavating will have to be made, but this can easily be done by the bigger boys.

The cost of a new and larger furnace will be

$450.00

I trust you will not consider these further demands unreasonable. Indian Agent McLeod without a doubt will readily endorse them.

May I take this opportunity to say how grateful I feel for the favor you have bestowed on Mr. Grimshaw.

Yours respectfully,

With further reference to the matter of the construction of a cow barn at the Cariboo Indian Residential School, Williams Lake Agency, I beg to say that recently I received a letter from Mr. Indian Agent MacLeod stating that Reverend Principal Maillard had informed him that he was satisfied that Brother G. Lajoie, O.M.I., the carpenter, was fully qualified to superintend the erection of the barn. By this I take it that he considers there will be no necessity to appoint a building inspector.

I note in your letter of the 27th ultimo that you say that funds will not be available for the refrigerator at this school. However, in connection with this refrigerating system, the Principal has stated that he believes the "Kelvinator" electric system would suit his school better than the system installed at the Kamloops School, because the "Kelvinator" could be operated from the Delco plant and it would cost less. The system, he claims, can be installed at the School for $975, whereas the style of electric plant for the refrigerator at the Kamloops School would cost $1,400 and the power would have to be purchased. This information I am conveying to you in the event of it eventually being determined to install a refrigerating plant for the Williams Lake School, which, to my mind, is as essential at that place as at Kamloops.

I have asked Agent MacLeod to notify the Principal that there are no funds available for the erection of a refrigerator at this School, as noted in your letter of the 27th ultimo.

Dear Sir,

Yours of the 16th instant to hand and note what you say re White machines.

As you are aware we sell to the institution at the actual net price that we have to turn over to our company, consequently we can not make the old machine allowance as we do in the regular family trade. I think we can get around that, Mr. MacLeod, in this way; we will quote you the regular school price as in the past. When you receive the machine you can place the White machines in the same crates, ship them in here and we will fix them up in as good shape as we can and sell them, refund you the proceeds, less actual cost of fitting them up. I think I would be safe in saying we could get you from $30.00 to $35.00 for the four. It may seem small but not knowing what they may be like we have to go on the safe side. I personally have to become good for the net amount of the Singers you get.

I might say there is a slight change in the price since you last got a new machine from use. It came into effect October of this year. The machine which the Department always buys, known as 127-3-2 oak, 5 dr., was $38.40 net. The last price is $42.84 net.

I don't know that we have had any orders from the Department since the new price went into effect.

We should not allow any more than $25.00 for the four old machines but if it will assist in getting the order through we would undertake to make it between $30.00 and $35.00.

Trusting you will be able to favor us with your order, we remain,

Yours truly,
SINGER SEWING MACHINE CO.

Dear Sir,

A week ago I wrote to Colonel Pragnell, our Inspector in connection with a magnificent bull which is for sale. I suggested the department to buy it for us for our milch herd.

The prize is rather high.

There are other things more needed than a bull. The number of our pupils has been increased and it is a very difficult task for our good Sister to prepare the food on the same range. A larger one is required which would cost over $600. As domestic science plays an important part in the education of the Indian girls, I am appealing to you...
again for assistance. I know if you were here, you would not refuse my request, and rather than fail, you would decide to give us a good range. Our children are well. No measles yet and I hope we keep them away from our doors. But it is cold—every morning the thermometer is below freezing.

I am yours sincerely,

February 1, 1927.

Dear Father Rohr:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, with reference to general conditions at the Cariboo Indian Residential School. I am very grateful for the photos of Indians of the Lillooet district.

I was very grieved to learn of the epidemic of flu and the death of two pupils. I have directed that an item be placed in our Estimates for the coming year, so that something can be done to arrange for better heating facilities. A note will be taken in connection with the infirmary requirements. The appropriations for Indian Education are so limited each fiscal year, that I regret I cannot be hopeful concerning an automobile for this school. I trust that you will have a very useful career at Cariboo.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

I appreciate sincerely your favor in allowing me to increase the number of our pupils from eighty to ninety. In the name of the Indians of this agency I extend to you my thanks.

Under the same cover I am sending you a little collection of photos of some Indians of my former district in Selkoot. I hope you will like them.

This new year has been very trying for our school. More than once I felt discouraged. We had an epidemic of flu - one boy died on January 2nd.

Another one of mornings on January 11th. Besides the weather became terribly cold and stormy. It was impossible to heat up the school buildings.

Something must be done as it would be criminal to let both staff and children suffer as they did this year.

There is no infirmary here—neither for boys nor for girls. The hospital is 12 miles from here. To remove them there we have to hire each time a closed car.

I promised the staff, especially the good sisters, that I would appeal to you. I am sure you will help us—and have some appropriation voted for the Cariboo Industrial School before the session closes.

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian Education

In connection with my report on the Estimates for the Fiscal Year 1927-28, I dealt only with the item for General Administration, leaving out anything pertaining to Indian Education.

Another Pease Economy Furnace is required for the boys' building of the Williams Lake School. Necessary repairs to the walls and floors in the basement are much needed as the children feel the cold in the winter very severely.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) W. E. DITCHBURN,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.
Sir,

I have the honour to report further in reply to your letter of May 19th, No.160-45 that I examined the basement of the boys' building at the school on May 31st. I find that it is necessary to do considerable excavation work in order to do the work properly. It is 32 by 64 ft size and is now about half excavated. When finished it should be 8 feet high.

With Rev.V.Rohr, Principal of the School, I visited Williams Lake in order to interview contractors and others re doing the work. The only man there who could do the work wanted $2.00 per day for himself; $4.50 for his helper and said he would require two or three others to help him while excavating at $3.00 per day each. I thought this too high. Rev. Father Anthony who has had experience at this sort of work has offered to perform the labour at $6.00 per day and would need from one to three labourers at $3.00 per day each. The Department would buy the materials, namely, lumber, (about $100.00 worth) cement, etc. The basement that Rev. Father Anthony would put in would have a concrete floor. The complete basement is necessary for a recreation room for the boys during the winter cold spells and also for the furnace and wood.

After examining the buildings I am of the opinion that they should be painted and papered in order to make them warmer. This should be done before the winter sets in again. The present is about the best time of the year to do the work, before the haying season commences. If the Department approves of the repairs and improvements I would suggest that the authority to proceed be wired to me.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

During your last inspection of our school, you drew my attention to the worn out condition of the different floors of our school and the urgent need of fire escapes.

Rev. Fr. Anthony and myself took the measurements of the different rooms in all the school buildings where new floors are needed and we estimated it would take 18,000 feet of flooring.

With regard to the fire escapes, there should be at least one for each building, rather two for the convent.
The Cariboo Indian Residential School
Post Office: 150 Mile House
British Columbia

Thanking you for the great interest you always have taken in our institution; and the strenuous work you have done in this agency for the welfare of the Indians.

Yours very devotedly,

[Signature]
Principal.
I would suggest wooden stairs, built outside of each building and connected with the dormitories. It could be done easily if we had the means. This must be done, otherwise I will not be responsible for the lives of the little children.

As you know the conditions of the Cariboo, I appeal to you, dear Sir, to explain the matter to the Department. We have no complaints to make. The officials of the Department have always been kind to us and never refused us any assistance when in need.

Writers is the most appropriate room to do repair work here—inside. Also it would give some useful occupation to the older boys under the direction of Brother Lafrie. If possible, or if funds are still available for the Cariboo Indian School, I would earnestly beg you, dear Sir, to ask the Department not to hesitate to let us have at once 18,000 feet of flooring and $500 feet of stopping & 10 pieces 2x3x50
Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith original letter received from the Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School which speaks for itself.

As you know, the Department has not advised me what funds are available for this School. If funds are available or were appropriated sufficiently large to permit the proper repairs being made, undoubtedly the floors should be replaced. They are in a very bad condition. There are several holes and patches on them and it is difficult to keep them clean. To place linoleum on these floors in their present condition would be a waste.

The occupiers should have been provided years ago and should a fire occur in one of these buildings loss of life would be certain.

Not having actual cost figures of flooring lumber before me I am not certain as to the cost but I find it costs in buying it would come to approximately $50.00 per M. delivered to the nearest station, owing to the high freight rates on the C.G.R.R. from the Coast where the lumber would be purchased.

It is evident that the management is willing to do the work if supplied with the materials.

An early reply will oblige me, while

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have the honour to report that I visited the Cariboo Indian Residential School on the 29th ultimo particularly to examine the progress of the repairs to the buildings.

I found that the four walls of the basement to the boys' quarters were completed and also an outside entrance of concrete and about a forty foot closed-in approach from one end, consisting of concrete walk from six to eight feet high was almost complete.

The location where the new furnace is located on the floor is built about eighteen inches lower than the level of the floor and has a large concrete airshaft from the base of the furnace to the ground foundation of the nearest new concrete wall, thence to the surface of the ground along the outside wall. This is for the purpose of supplying cold fresh air from the outside to the bottom of the hot air furnace and thence throughout the building.

It was necessary to build two new chimneys, one for the new furnace and one for the new kitchen range. These two chimneys required a lot of cement as did also the side and end entrances to the buildings and as a consequence the cement ordered is not sufficient to complete the flooring in the basement. I am requested by the Rev. Principal to supply another fifty sacks of cement in order to complete the flooring. This cement will cost more per sack than the last we got owing to the local freight rate charge instead of the carload rate we got on the first lot. May I please be advised of the Department's pleasure in this matter?

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

I have the honour to be,
Your obedient servant,

Sir,

The boilers, or tanks, are certainly necessary to heat water for the boys' bathroom. There should be two, containing thirty gallons each, and these will be attached to the furnace.

Dear Sir,

I am sending you sketch and estimate cost of proposal addition to the girls school premises. It is a real pity that our application should be too late for consideration. We need greater accommodation for the ever increasing number of our pupils. Also in case of an epidemic we would again be handicapped. We are far away from doctors. Only twice or three times we had a medical man to visit us last year. A few weeks ago we had the smallpox scare. Fortunately the doctor advised me over the phone that it was only chickenpox. It lasted three weeks and through the care of our devoted staff and especially Almighty God's protection, I am glad to tell you that every vestige of the dreaded disease has disappeared. All our children are doing well.

Sir,

I have the honour to report that the Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School, 150 Mile House P.O., this agency, has drawn to my attention the crowded state of the girls' dormitories and the necessity of a recreation room and an infirmary. It is quite true that the girls' dormitories are rather overcrowded and that pupils when sick have to be nursed in the dormitories with the well children. The sewing room has to be used as a recreation room.

The Principal asks that I draw the situation to the attention of the Department with a view of getting an addition of 30 x 50 to the girls' building.

There is no doubt that we could have more girl pupils in this Institution if we add on to the girls' building but of course this is a matter for the Department to decide.

Ottawa, June 21st, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, relative to the supplying of new flooring material and an ice house for the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

Regarding the flooring, I beg to say that the Department will approve of the expenditure required in the supplying of 12,000 feet of edge grain fir flooring. You should arrange for the purchase of this flooring, after obtaining competitive prices, from the firm quoting the lowest price. You should see that a good grade of flooring is supplied. Please submit an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the material and the freight charges on same. A receipt for the amount of the freight charges should be attached to the voucher. It is understood that the work of laying this flooring will be performed by the school authorities without expense to the Department.

Regarding the ice house, I would refer you to official letter of the 13th instant, asking you to state whether the Principal would rather that the account covering the cost of the materials used in painting the school building be paid or the ice house be erected. If the erection of the ice house is more urgent, please state whether this is required for the storage of ice only, or whether a cold storage chamber for the storage of meat and other supplies should be included. In the latter event, the cost would be considerably in excess of the erection of a house for the storage of ice only. Particulars should be given as to the dimensions of the building required. When we have a reply to our letter of the 13th instant, referred to above, and particulars as to the type of ice house, consideration will then be given to authorizing having this work carried out.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. E. Taylor, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Clinton, B.C.
Sir,

I have the honour to reply as follows to your letter of the 31st May last, relative to new flooring and ice-house required for the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

Since receiving your letter, I have visited the school and personally inspected the floors. I find that a lot of the flooring is in exceptionally poor condition and badly needs replacing.

Last year, the school principal requested 18,000 feet of flooring, and of this amount, 6,000 was supplied by the Department.

The principal now requests the remainder, 12,000 feet of edge grain fir flooring, and I have no doubt that it will be put to good and immediate use. The price paid last year, F.O.B. Vancouver, was $40.00 per thousand. I understand that it is not possible to get good flooring in this district. They have tried it at the school before, but it is too soft, and does not wear well. It would therefore be advisable to purchase the flooring again in Vancouver.

With regard to the ice-house mentioned in your letter, I found, when at the school, that there is no provision for keeping meat etc., during the summer months, except one small electric refrigerator, which accommodates only a negligible quantity of food.

Quantities of ice are obtainable from close to the school, in the winter time, and I would recommend that authority be granted for the material for erecting a suitable ice-house.

Only two weeks ago, a large quantity of meat was spoiled at the school, through lack of proper storing facilities.

The school principal has requested me to inquire whether the Department have on hand any plans for ice-houses, as the staff have no knowledge of the correct way to build. If such information can be supplied, the lumber needed could be included in the order for flooring, thus keeping down the freight cost.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

H.E. Taylor

Sir:

Herewith I beg to submit report upon the Williams Lake Agency No. 8.

I visited the school twice, and stopped the night there. Rev. Father Mohr, the new Principal seems to have greatly improved the appearance of all the buildings; there is much in improvement. The school looks greatly improved and almost like a new building, with the new paint on it. Much improvement in the basement of the boys' wing has been done by a certain Father Anthony, who has cemented the same and placed the building on cement pillars. He has done a most excellent job, as the place was a veritable fire trap before. Possibly, the same may be done to the girls' buildings. He has also replaced the flooring in various places and has done a lot of work. He must be of great service to the Principal. The matter of screening against flies, should, however, be seen to as I am sure it cannot be sanitary as it is.

The crops on the school farm are excellent this year, but it is to be hoped that the scheme of raising lac le lache and thus ensuring no water for the school and the adjacent sugar cane reserves will be undertaken. I have recommended this before.

While the children are being well fed at the school the school is somewhat short in its milk supply. Some more good cows should be purchased.

We now come to the matter of fire protection for these buildings. Great improvement has been made by the erection of fire escapes at the end of each building, even though these are merely a system of gently graded wooden stairs. However, some form of fire alarm should be installed. This would not be expensive and would lead to a system of fire drill. Further, there are no chemical fire extinguishers. Two or three large ones and several smaller ones should be placed at various strategic points. Finally too, fire axes, in glass cases, one at each door of the fire escapes should be placed. This is necessary on account of the possible danger of the doors freezing against their sills in winter. Cheap ones as were fixed up locally for the Kamloops School could be used.

Sir;

I have the honour to inform you that when on a visit to the Cariboo Indian Residential School on the 22nd inst., I was requested by the Principal to ascertain if the Department could supply a set of new batteries for the school Delco lighting plant.

The present batteries have been in use nearly four years and are now worn out and the resultant poor light necessitates the use at times of lamps and candles, which constitute a fire hazard and cause much inconvenience.

A set of batteries consists of sixteen. The Delco plant is of thirty-two volts and thirteen-plate batteries are required. If possible, one battery should be fitted with a pilot-ball which shows a reading of the condition of the batteries.

Delco batteries are supplied in Vancouver by Bruce Robinson Electric B.C. Ltd., 544 Howe Street, Vancouver, B.C.

If it is possible to meet the wishes of the school Principal in this matter, there will be a considerable improvement in the school lighting system.

I have the honour to be,

I have the honour to inform you that I visited the Cariboo Indian Residential School on the 22nd inst., and whilst there, the principal stressed the need for a larger oven for the school bakery.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of August 20th last, in which you gave instructions for the obtaining of a price for the installation of an electric fire alarm system in the Cariboo Indian Residential School, I have the honour to report as follows:

There is only one electrician in Williams Lake, which is the only settlement near the school. This is Mr. Keith Caverly, and in September last I took him to the school, and, in consultation with the staff, asked him to report upon a system of fire alarm, together with a price for installing same.

I have only recently received his report, and submit the following particulars for your consideration:

There are three school buildings which need to be equipped with fire gongs. Of these, the boys' and girls' dormitories are more than one hundred yards apart, which will necessitate a considerable quantity of wiring.

Going to the main building, and their consequent installation, it is considered advisable to have all wiring enclosed in metal conduit, for safety.

The system would be operated off the Delco light plant at present used by the School.

A six inch gong would be installed in each of the following places: the boys' dormitory, the girls' dormitory, and the staff quarters.

The gongs would be rung by means of breakable glass alarm boxes, which would be placed conveniently as follows: two in boys' dormitory (one upstairs and one down), two in girls' dormitory (one upstairs and one down) and one in staff quarters.

In addition, there would be a three way alarm installed in the staff quarters, by means of which a general alarm could be sounded in all buildings, either for practice fire drill, or in case of real fire. Thus, three way alarm is to constituted so it can be operated without breaking the regular boxes, and will ring the bells in any or all of the three buildings separately or simultaneously.

As the large gongs cost in the neighbourhood of $65.00 each, I asked that small gongs be specified, as I am informed that they are sufficiently loud for ordinary buildings of this size. I have requested that nothing unnecessarily expensive be used in the way of material, but that durability and safety receive consideration.

The price submitted by Mr. Caverly for material, and all labour of installation is $375.00.

I have the honour to be,

SIR,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Re: Water Supply to St. Joseph's Mission, Williams Lake Agency

In accordance with your instructions of October 6th, 1928, an investigation was made of the water supply to St. Joseph's Mission. The results of this investigation, together with proposed improvements, are discussed in detail below.

GENERAL

As shown on key plan attached, St. Joseph's Mission is situated on the San Jose river, about four miles upstream from the head of Williams Lake.

The Mission is owned by the Order of Oblates of Mary Immaculate, which conducts boarding schools for Indian children, and carries on farming and stock raising operations on a large farm surrounding the school buildings.

The number of pupils enrolled in the boys' and girls' schools is about 100. In addition to these are the teaching and administration staffs, and the farm workers. The total population of the Mission is approximately 125.

The Mission buildings include a chapel, boys' and girls' dormitories and schools, barns, outhouses, etc., as shown on Plan No. 1. These are all of frame construction, and the main administrative buildings are of two stories.

EXISTING WATER SUPPLY, RECORDED RIGHTS AND ANALYSES OF WATER.

The supply of water for domestic use in

C.E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dom. Water Power & Reclamation Service,
Vancouver, B.C.
the Mission is at present derived from the San Jose river. The water is directed by ditch into Yellow Lake (shown on Plan No.1), and from this storage, is conveyed through a 4-inch wood stave pipe to the Mission, under a head of about 40 feet.

The right to use water for domestic purposes is recorded under C.L. 8799, with priority January 26, 1927, which grants the use of 25,000 gallons per day. Storage rights for 100 acre-feet per annum are held on Yellow Lake under C.L. 8668. Analysis was made of the water supply from Yellow Lake, in October, 1928, and it was pronounced to be polluted and unfit for domestic use. Copy of analysis is attached as Appendix "C". A further analysis shown in Appendix "D", made in December, 1928, of water from the same source, shows it to be safe for domestic use though of poor quality. This sample was taken when there was a large diversion from San Jose river into Yellow lake, and was practically a sample of river water.

These analyses would seem to show that contamination of the water came largely from Yellow lake, and that it should be discontinued as a source of domestic supply. The investigation, therefore, is to determine the most feasible means of providing an unpolluted domestic supply.

SAN JOSE RIVER SUPPLY

As previously stated, a conditional licence is held granting the daily use of 25,000 gallons from San Jose river for domestic purposes.
The maximum feasible gravity head available from the San Jose is about 40 feet. This is sufficient for ordinary purposes but is of no use for fire protection which is most necessary.

By use of a ram and reservoir, however, a sufficient supply for both domestic and fire protection purposes could be obtained, and a system from this source will be discussed later in the report.

**SPRING SUPPLY**

The only discoverable source of water supply other than the San Jose river was found in a spring lying, as shown on Plan No. 1., about four miles to the south. The elevation of this spring above the Mission is about 400 feet.

Analysis of the water from this spring, copy of which is attached as Appendix "E", shows it to be of fair quality, free from animal contamination but containing a small amount of decomposed vegetable matter. By thoroughly cleaning out and covering the spring it is thought that vegetable decomposition may be eliminated. At the time of inspection, 6th November, 1928, the flow in the spring was pretty well down to its minimum. The discharge at that time was 3/4 cubic feet per second.

Although the absolute minimum flow is not definitely known, from information received locally it is estimated to be not less than 1/4 second foot. This is equivalent to more than 125,000 gallons per day, which is in excess of all requirements as discussed below.
REQUIREMENTS OF ST. JOSEPH'S MISSION

(1) Domestic Supply.

As previously stated, the population of St. Joseph's Mission is about 125. Assuming a daily consumption of 40 gallons per head, the requirement for domestic supply would be 5000 gallons per day.

(2) Fire Protection.

The buildings comprising St. Joseph's Mission are of wood frame construction, and are not equipped with any system for protection against fire.

The present water system cannot supply the pressure necessary for fire protection, but this would be amply provided by a pumping system from the San Jose river direct, or by a gravity system from the spring mentioned above, and in view of the large number of children housed in the buildings, adequate fire protection is considered necessary. For this a supply of not less than 600 gallons per minute should be available for three fire streams.

POSSIBLE SYSTEM FROM SAN JOSE RIVER

To adequately supply the demands of St. Joseph's Mission for domestic and fire protection purposes, a system from the San Jose river would consist of the following units:

1. Hydraulic Rams.

This unit of the system would include a small intake in the San Jose river, about 400 feet of 4" drive pipe, and a double ram installation. The latter is necessary in this isolated locality in case one ram should go out of order.
2. Ram Delivery Pipe.

To deliver water supply from the site of the ram to the site of storage reservoir near the Mission would require about 3000 feet of 3-inch pipe.

3. Storage Reservoir.

To ensure an adequate supply of water for fire protection, a reinforced concrete, covered storage reservoir would be necessary near the Mission, and at an elevation of about 170 feet above the buildings. The reservoir capacity should be 56,000 gallons to make available an hour's supply for three fire streams. Design of this proposed reservoir is shown on Plan No. 3.

4. Filter.

In view of the analyses of San Jose river water (taken from Yellow lake) shown in Appendices 2 and 3, and owing to the fact that the river above the ram site meanders for fifteen miles through swampy and meadow lands, it is considered altogether undesirable to use the river water for cooking and drinking without filtration.

A mechanical filter, therefore, is recommended, either a Paradon Chlorinizer or a filter of a similar type, that will treat a domestic water supply of 5000 gallons per day. This filter would be located near the storage reservoir, at an elevation low enough to provide operating head.

For treatment of water for domestic use a small tank of about 5000 gallons capacity would be built below the filter. Water supply to this tank would be provided by a small pipe from the main...
storage reservoir, and service pipes would lead direct from the tank to the various buildings.

The filter and treatment tank would have to be covered for protection against frost.

5. Reservoir Discharge Pipes and Distribution System.

For fire protection service a length of about 1500 feet of 10" pressure pipe would be necessary to serve the fire hydrants, as shown on Plan No. 2. From this main, service pipes could be run to the laundry, etc.

To accommodate overflow, about 2500 feet of 2" pipe would be required between the reservoir and the river at the Mission.

6. Fire Fighting Equipment.

For adequate fire protection the following equipment is considered necessary:

Five outside hydrants housed in small shelters, and equipped with 150 feet of 2½ inch hose, hose bracket, and standard nozzle.

Six inside hydrants, placed one on each floor of the three main buildings, and equipped with hose bracket, 50 feet of 2-inch hose and 5/8 inch nozzle.

COST OF SYSTEM

Estimate of cost is shown in Appendix "A", and amounts to approximately $16,100.00.

POSSIBLE SYSTEM FROM SPRING

A gravity system from this source to St. Joseph's Mission would include the following:
1. Concrete Intake at the spring.
The spring should also be fenced to prevent contamination from ranging stock.

2. Pipe Line from Intake to Storage Tank.
This would be low pressure 3" pipe about 15,000 feet in length.

3. Storage Reservoir.
This would be of the same size as specified for the system from San Jose river.
The elevation of this tank above the buildings would have to be about 185 feet to allow for friction losses in discharge pipe.

4. Reservoir Discharge Pipes and Distribution System.
From the reservoir to the fire hydrants about 3000 feet of 10" pressure pipe would be required.
Service pipes to all buildings could be run direct from this main.
About 2000' of 2" pipe would be required to carry the overflow from the reservoir to the river.

5. Fire Fighting Equipment.
This would be the same as specified for the system from San Jose river.

COST OF SYSTEM
Estimate of cost is shown in Appendix "B", and amounts to approximately $25,500.00.

SUMMARY
San Jose River System.
To fill the requirements of St. Joseph's
Mission with respect to domestic water supply and fire protection, a ram system would be necessary to pump the supply to a storage reservoir. For domestic use, owing to the poor quality of the water, a portion of this supply should be filtered.

The ram, storage, and filter units would need regular supervision and periodical cleaning.

The cost of this installation is estimated to be $16,100.00.

System from Springs.

This is a gravity system over three miles in length. Analysis of water from this source shows that no filtration is necessary. This system would require the minimum of attention.

The estimated cost of installation is $25,500.00.

Recommendations.

From an analysis of the two systems summarized above, it is considered that, though costing $9500.00 more, the gravity system from the spring would ultimately be cheaper and more satisfactory.

The reasons advanced for this conclusion are:

1) The gravity system would need no expert mechanical supervision as would be the case with the ram and filter on the San Jose system.

2) The gravity system is derived from a pure source, and the water supply could be delivered direct without filtration.

3) The gravity system offers greater assurance of regular and uninterrupted supply.
In the case of the San Jose system, the intake for the ram is located below the irrigation ditches intakes, and there is a possibility, though it is believed to be a remote one, that, during a summer of abnormally small flow in the San Jose river, the water supply passing the irrigation ditch intakes might be reduced below the quantity required for efficient operation of the ram.

In view of the above, the installation of the gravity system from the spring is recommended.

Your obedient servant,

F. R. Archibald
Division Hydrometric Engineer.

Sir,

I enclose herewith a report received from Mr. Webb on an investigation of a water supply system for the St. Joseph's Mission in the Williams Lake Agency, B.C. This report was prepared at the request of Mr. Indian Commissioner Ditchburn in a letter to Mr. Webb dated October 15th last.

One, a water supply from the San Jose river at an estimated cost of $16,100; the other, from a spring three miles distant from the mission at an estimated cost of $23,500. While the cost of these schemes is considerable it is recommended by Mr. Webb that the expenditure is warranted in view of the fact that every precaution should be taken to protect the lives of the inmates of this institution from a sanitary standpoint as well as to afford fire protection. Should it be found that there are not sufficient funds to carry out either of the proposals outlined in the report, it is recommended that immediate steps should be taken towards the purification, as far as possible, of the domestic water supply from Yellow lake.

Dear Sir:

I beg to make the following report upon my last visit to this agency.

SCHOOL

Cariboo Residential school. In company with the acting principal, Rev. Father Patterson, I went over the institute. I found things in excellent order with the school filled to capacity. It was glad to note that there were several children from the Chilcotin entered at the school, and they seemed happy and contented.

It is to be hoped that the prejudice of the Chilcotin Indians against the school has at last been overcome. With this field added and recruiting elsewhere accommodation for 50 more children at least will be required in the near future. This would be more economical than building in the Chilcotin. There is of course still no pressure water system for fire purposes, though I understand planned. Dependence there should be placed upon chemical fire extinguishers. I could find no large chemical extinguishers, anyone in position, and the acting principal could not inform me whether any had been supplied. If not this should be attended to immediately. Fire Drill has been started in the school and the children well trained. I went over the manual training class room and am told the boys are working well at this work. The school would well do with two or three foremen for blacksmith training. I also accompanied Principal to the intake of their irrigation system on St Josephs Creek, this matter will be dealt with in my remarks upon the Sugar Cane Reserve.

Sir: Re - St. Joseph's Mission Domestic Water Supply

As instructed in your letter of July 3, 1929 investigations were carried out to determine what compulsory measures could be adopted to purify the supply of domestic water from Yellow Lake to St. Joseph's Mission. Detailed below is the result of these investigations and of their discussion with Father Patterson, acting superintendent of St. Joseph's Mission.

Yellow Lake is an artificial reservoir filled by flow through a ditch from the San Jose River, and used for the storage of irrigation supply for use on lands lying west of the river, and of domestic supply for St. Joseph's Mission.

The bed of Yellow Lake, for some distance from the shore, was found to be thickly covered with an under-water weed growth, which appeared to attain its densest growth at the lake outlet where the intake pipe for St. Joseph's Mission domestic water supply is located.

This weed growth seems to be the only source of pollution in and immediately surrounding the lake. There appears to be very little danger of nearly pollution from animal matter, as the lake is in a cultivated area that is very well fenced.

The pipe intake is located about 100 feet from the shore at the lake outlet, but at a depth of only between three and four feet below the lake surface, so that though the plant growth on the lake bed is very dense, the pipe intake is above it.

At the time of investigation there was a large flow both into and out of the lake, and if this condition could be maintained it is believed that the danger of pollution would be minimized, as the pipe intake is located at the lake outlet and the water drawn through the pipe is not stagnant but running water drawn from the San Jose River. Extension of the pipe intake into the lake for another two or three hundred feet would also lessen the danger of pollution as that would remove it from the dense area of weed growth on the lake bed.
When discussing the matter with Father Patterson, it was suggested that the plant growth be removed from the lake bed, that the intake pipe be extended farther into the lake, that chemical treatment, say with copper sulphate, be given the lake water, and that a chlorinator be installed in the existing storage tank above the Mission buildings.

Father Patterson was not in favour of anything being done at the present time, stating that in his opinion the present water supply was as pure as could be obtained from the San Jose River, and that the removal of plant growth would stir up bacteria that would pollute the supply for some time to come.

With respect to the extension of the intake pipe, Father Patterson stated that the Mission authorities proposed to do this themselves later in the season, when the lake surface was lowered.

The installation of a chlorinator in the storage tank did not find favour with Father Patterson as he considered that anything of a drastic nature done at the present time would be prejudicial to the later installation of a combined domestic supply and fire protection system. At present the storage tank is regularly treated with lime and periodically flushed.

Father Patterson stated that he and others of the Order at the Mission, were strongly in favour of the proposed gravity system, and opposed to any system that drew its supply from the San Jose River. In addition to the objections of inferior quality of supply, and the necessity for supervision and maintenance of mechanical pumping and purification units, he spoke of an objectional practice that had not been brought to his attention. He stated that when the flow in the river was low, and the demand for purification thereof at its peak, the owners of meadows bordering the river between the Mission and Lac La Hache were in the habit of dumping manure therefor back-flooding purposes, and that to do this large quantities of manure were used. This of course might create a dangerous condition and unless it can be stopped is a very strong argument against the use of the San Jose River as a source of domestic water supply.

In view of the attitude of the St. Joseph's Mission authorities as stated above, it appears that no immediate steps can be taken with respect to improving the domestic supply to the Mission.

Father Patterson informed me that Father Rohr expects to call at the office of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs on his return from Europe, and intends to argue as forcefully as possible for an early installation of the gravity system to provide both fire protection and domestic water supply.

Your obedient servant,

C. E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,

Sir,

Re Water Supply, St. Joseph's Mission School, Williams Lake Agency.

In connection with the above project we have made application on behalf of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs for a water right from the springs which are the proposed source of supply.

I have recently been requested by the Comptroller of Water Rights to advise him as to why this right should not be in the name of the Mission as they are the registered owners of the land where the water is to be used. Mr. Ditchburn feels that the Department should obtain this water right in their own name in view of the large expenditure to be made and it was for this reason that we made application in the name of the Superintendent General.

I have discussed the question with the office of the Comptroller and they advise that without a legal hold on the land we cannot obtain a domestic right on the water. It was suggested we might obtain the right-of-way from the School and by doing so control the works even if the school had the license to the water. This, however, is a point which is open to question in my mind. I suggest that the granting of a Class "C" license which is the kind issued for water works purposes, where a toll is charged, but they pointed out that while possibly the Water Act might permit the granting of such a license, such was not the intention of the Act, even if it is so worded. In this connection Sec. 11 (4) of the Water Act states:

"A Class C license may be acquired by any municipality, company, association, or body corporate whose undertaking in respect of such license has been approved under this Act."

You will note a "body corporate" may acquire a Class C license and in this connection would you please advise if the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs or the Department of Indian Affairs are legally a "body corporate".

I have advised Mr. Ditchburn as to the standing of this matter and understand he is strongly pressing his Department to obtain a legal hold on the school property as a means of protecting their investment in this proposed water supply system.

In the meantime we are preparing to advertise for tenders for the installation of the proposed system and hope to have the question of the licence settled by the time the tenders are received so that work may be completed before winter sets in.

Your obedient servant,

J.T. Johnston, Esq., C.E.,
Director,

In further reference to your letter of June 24th regarding the installation of a new water system to supply the St. Joseph's Mission school in the Williams Lake Agency, I enclose herewith copy of a letter received from Mr. Webb regarding obtaining a water license from the province to cover the domestic supply.

You will note that Mr. Webb asks to be advised if the Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs or the Department of Indian Affairs are legally a body corporate to come within the provisions of Section II, Subsection 4 of the British Columbia Water Act. Whether this is so or not, however, does not appear to materially change the situation. The basis of the Provincial Water Act is that licenses are appurtenant to the land on which the water is to be used and are issued in the name of the owner, as defined in the act, of the appurtenant land.

If it is desired that the license should be issued in the name of the Superintendent-General it would appear necessary that the Department should own an interest in the land on which the water works are constructed, or on which the water is used.
