PART IV

DETAILED SPECIFICATIONS

Reservoir

The reservoir shall be of concrete construction reinforced with 1/2-inch, 5/8-inch and 3/4-inch round steel rods.

It shall be built to the dimensions shown on the plan.

It shall be finished in a workmanlike manner and when completed, the inside walls, floor, and ceiling shall be given one coating of cement plaster, the outside walls a coating of pitch applied hot, and the roof a coating of asphalt not less than 1/4-inch in thickness.

HYDRANT HOUSES

Hydrant houses shall be of frame construction, built in a substantial manner of No.1 grade material and securely fastened to foundations.

Roofing shall be of best quality 3-ply prepared roofing of fire resisting type.

The doors shall be substantially made and hung and shall have fasteners as shown on plan.

Completed houses shall be given two coats of oil stain.

VALVE BOXES

Valve boxes shall be of concrete construction built to such dimensions as shown on the plan and finished in a workmanlike manner.

CONCRETE

All concrete used in the construction of the above buildings shall be composed of the following
ingredients proportioned by volume into what is known as a 1:2:4 mixture:

- Cement: 1 part
- Fine aggregate: 2 parts
- Coarse aggregate: 4 parts
- Water

**CEMENT**

The cement shall be a first-class Portland cement, of standard brand, free from lumps or foreign matter, and until it is used shall be stored in a building which will protect it from the weather.

**FINE AGGREGATE**

Fine aggregate shall consist of sand, crushed stone or gravel screenings; the particles shall be hard, dense and durable and such that they will pass through a 1/4-inch mesh screen. It shall be clean and free from soft particles, clay, loam and all organic matter; and it shall be so graded that when dry and well-shaken the voids will not exceed thirty per cent.

**COARSE AGGREGATE**

Coarse aggregate shall consist of crushed stone or gravel having its smallest particles approximately 1/4 inch in diameter and its largest particles approximately 1½ inches in diameter. It shall be graded from the smallest to the largest particles and shall be clean, hard, durable and free from all deleterious matter.

**WATER**

Water used in mixing concrete shall be free from oil, acid, alkalies or organic matter.

**MIXING**

A mixer of the type which ensures the uniform proportioning of the materials throughout the mass shall be used for mixing the concrete and the mixing shall continue for at least one minute after all the ingredients are assembled in the mixer.
CONSISTENCY

The materials shall be mixed wet enough to produce a concrete of such consistency that it will flow sluggishly into the forms and about the metal reinforcements and which, at the same time, can be conveyed from the mixer to the forms without separation of the coarse aggregate from the mortar.

STEEL REINFORCEMENT

All steel reinforcement used shall be of medium hardness, free from excessive rust, scales or coating, and shall conform to the standard specifications for Concrete Reinforcement Bars of the American Society for testing materials.

SPLICING

No splicing of reinforcement bars will be allowed at points receiving stress; and all splices made are to be subject to the approval of the engineer and may be rejected by him at the contractor's expense, should he deem them to be unsatisfactory.

CEMENT PLASTER

Cement plaster used on the inside of the reservoir shall be mixed by weight in the following proportions:

- Portland cement: 1 part.
- Sand: 1 part.

It shall be applied uniformly so as to give a smooth finish and shall in no place be less than 3/32 of an inch in thickness.

WOOD STAVE PIPE

All wood stave pipe called for in these specifications shall be of 3-inch diameter wood stave with steel double coupling and double burlap jacket.
Joints shall be coated and wrapped as hereinafter stated in these specifications.

STEEL PIPE

All 6" diameter steel pipe called for in these specifications shall be of standard 6" diameter bituminous-coated burlap-wrapped steel pipe, weighing not less than 11.5 lbs. per lineal foot exclusive of coating and wrapping. All 3" diameter steel pipe called for in these specifications shall be of standard 3" diameter bituminous-coated, burlap-wrapped steel pipe weighing not less than 4.5 lbs. per lineal foot exclusive of coating and wrapping. The pipes may be of random lengths, but their average length when taken over all shall not be less than 18'.

The pipes shall be straight and shall be true circles in cross-section with their inner and outer surfaces concentric.

They shall be smooth, free from dents, scales or lumps or any other defect which may unfit them for the purpose for which they are intended.

No plugging or filling will be allowed.

PIPE JOINTS FOR STEEL PIPE

All pipe joints for steel pipe shall be either standard hub and spigot lead-filled joints, or welded joints, as directed by the engineer, except where flanges are necessary to connect to flanged or screw fittings.

LEAD-FILLED JOINTS IN STEEL PIPE

Lead-filled joints of 6" diameter steel pipe shall contain not less than \( \frac{1}{2} \) of a pound of hemp yarn and 3\( \frac{1}{2} \) pounds of lead.
Lead-filled joints of 3" diameter steel pipe shall contain not less than \( \frac{1}{4} \) of a pound of hemp yarn and 2 pounds of lead.

Joints shall be poured hot and finished in a workmanlike manner and so made that when they are completed they shall be capable of withstanding a pressure of 200 pounds per square inch.

**WELDED JOINTS**

Each welded joint, if used, shall be made by the oxy-weld process, and shall be what is known as the butt-welded, chamfered-end type.

They shall be so made as to leave a smooth surface on the inside of the pipe, and shall be subject to the approval of the engineer.

**COATING AND WRAPPING OF JOINTS**

All joints, shall, when finished, be coated with hot asphalt and burlap wrapped in such a manner that they shall have the same protection as the remainder of the pipe.

All coating and wrapping shall be subject to the approval of the engineer.

**FLANGED JOINTS FOR STEEL PIPE**

Where flanged joints are required to connect to flanged fittings, the pipe may be cut, threaded and standard cast-iron flanges fitted thereto.

**CAST-IRON PIPE**

All cast-iron pipe called for in these specifications shall be made of good quality cast-iron, strong, tough and of even grain, and free from all scales, lumps, blisters, blow-holes, sand-holes, and "cold-shots", etc.
They shall be connected together where shown on plans by standard cast-iron flanges.

**LAND TILE**

All land tile supplied by the contractor shall be standard land tile of size specified, and no section shall be more than 18 inches in length.

Each section shall be straight and of uniform diameter and free from all bad holes, cracks, blisters, etc.

**CULVERT PIPE**

Culvert pipe shall be 12-inch diameter corrugated pipe of 16 gauge galvanized iron.

**GRADE**

All pipes shall be laid accurately to the required depth and on the required lines and grades called for in the plans accompanying these specifications and which will be staked out for the contractor by the engineer.

**CAST-IRON FITTINGS**

All cast-iron fittings called for in these specifications, including all cast-iron tees, elbows, spigots, reducers, reducing tees, flanges, etc., shall be of good standard quality and capable of performing the work for which they are designed.

They shall conform in size to the standard dimensions for such fittings and shall be subject to rejection by the engineer should he deem them unfit for the purpose for which they are required.

**GATE VALVES**

All valves called for in these specifications shall be of good quality, iron-body, bronze-mounted valves equipped with non-rising stems.
Where extension rods are required, these shall be connected in a workmanlike manner, and such connections shall be subject to the approval of the engineer.

AIR RELIEF VALVES

All air relief valves called for shall be of standard design, constructed of good quality brass, bronze or other material.

They shall be of such size as to be capable of removing the accumulated air from 2000 lineal feet of 3" diameter water main when this main is carrying a pressure of not more than 100 pounds per square inch.

They shall be capable of adjustment and so fitted that no leakage of water from the main shall take place when they are operating.

INTAKE SCREEN

Intake screen shall be of bronze or copper wire or other non-rusting material with a 6x6 mesh. The screening shall be set in a rigid metal frame which can be removed for cleaning purposes.

MANHOLE FRAMES AND COVERS

Manhole frames and covers shall be of good quality cast-iron of standard design and shall have a circular aperture as specified.

Covers shall be required to fit snugly into the places for which they are provided and when in place shall present a neat and workmanlike appearance.

HYDRANTS

All hydrants supplied by the contractor shall be standard 6" diameter body, bronze mounted flanged
Each hydrant shall be supplied with a drain valve in the base of the body so arranged that this drain valve shall be open when the hydrant is closed and closed when the hydrant is open.

They shall be connected to pipe line with flanged or leaded joint.

Where leaded joint is made, hydrant clamps must be provided to be securely fastened to second pipe length from hydrant, as shown on plans.

They shall be made suitable for use in a 5-foot trench.

They shall have two outlets 2½ inches in diameter, threaded with City of Vancouver hose thread. Each hydrant shall be fitted with one 2½-inch hydrant gate valve and shall be equipped with outlet caps and hydrant wrenches.

Installations shall be made by the contractor of hose valves and hose reels or brackets within the buildings, as shown on the plans. These shall be for 1½-inch hose connections.

GASKETS

Where copper gaskets are specified they shall be full face, of the required diameter and of 26 gauge sheet copper.

Where lead gaskets are specified they shall be half face, of the required diameter and of 18 gauge sheet lead.
BOLTS FOR CONNECTING FLANGES

All bolts used for connecting flanges shall be of steel of standard dimensions and not more than 1/8" smaller in diameter than the holes in the flanges through which they pass.

They shall be equipped with square heads and hexagon nuts and threaded so as to permit the nut to run the entire length of the thread.

NUTS

Nuts shall be hexagonal in shape and of sufficient thickness to ensure against stripping of threads.

PIPE COVERS

Pipe covers shall be of cast-iron and may be either flat or semi-spherical in shape.

They shall be of sufficient size to properly protect the opening in the pipe for which they are required and shall be so made that when they are in place they do not interfere with the entrance or exit of air into or from the pipe.

An approved method of fixing the pipe covers to the pipe so as to prevent their removal shall be devised and carried out by the contractor.

MISCELLANEOUS

All other miscellaneous fittings and other items of minor importance necessary to the installation of the above water supply system and not mentioned in detail in these specifications shall be supplied by the contractor and shall be subject to the approval of the engineer.
WORK

EXCAVATION

All excavation necessary for the proper installation and construction of the above buildings and pipe shall be undertaken by the contractor and the contractor will be required to carry such excavation down to the grade lines or stakes, as set out on the ground by the engineer, notwithstanding any errors or omissions in, or resulting from changes to, the plans accompanying these specifications.

BACKFILLING

The contractor will be required to perform all backfilling upon all pipe, buildings, fittings, etc., as may be considered necessary by the engineer, but no backfilling shall be carried out during the absence of the engineer or before the engineer has had sufficient time to inspect the work upon which the backfilling is to be placed.

Work covered up without due notice first having been given to the engineer shall be uncovered and re-covered at the contractor's expense.

PIPE LAYING AND TESTING

All pipe shall be laid in straight lines on even grades at a depth of not less than 5 feet below the surface of the ground when measured from the top of the pipe.

Where additional excavation is necessary to maintain these even grades, this excavation shall be undertaken by the contractor.
Where bends are required and elbows are not used for this purpose, the bends shall be made subject to the approval of the engineer.

All pipe installed by the contractor shall, before backfilling is carried out or before the pipe is covered in any way, be subjected by the contractor to either an hydraulic or air pressure test in the presence of the engineer so as to ensure that all joints are tight and properly made. All leaks found at the time of the test shall be made tight by the contractor.

The pressure which the pipe will be required to carry during this test shall not be less than 200 pounds or more than 250 pounds per square inch.

STEEL REINFORCEMENT

CLEANING

Steel reinforcement before being placed shall be thoroughly cleaned of rust, scale and coatings of any character that will destroy or reduce the bond.

Reinforcement appreciably decreased in section shall be rejected.

BENDING

Reinforcement shall be carefully formed to the dimensions indicated in the plans accompanying these specifications.

The radius of bends shall be 4 or more times the least diameter of the reinforcement bar.

STRAIGHTENING

Metal reinforcement shall not be bent or straightened in a manner that will injure the material. Bars with kinks or sharp bends shall not be used.
PLACING

Steel reinforcement shall be accurately placed and secured against displacement by using annealed iron wire of not less than No.18 gauge, or suitable clips at intersections, and shall be supported by concrete or metal chairs or spacers or by metal hangers.

Parallel bars shall not be placed closer than \( \frac{1}{2} \) times the diameter of round bars.

The reinforcement shall be firmly and accurately placed so that the centre of the bars shall be the exact distance from the inside of the nearest forms as required by the plans accompanying these specifications, and so fixed that no sagging of the reinforcement against or away from the forms while the concrete is being poured can take place.

SPLICING

Splicing of tension reinforcement at points of maximum stress will not be allowed. Splices where required shall provide sufficient lap to transfer the strain between bars by bond and shear.

GENERAL

All other work in connection with the above installation is to be carried out by the contractor in such a manner and by such methods as will, in the opinion of the engineer, ensure a satisfactory quality of work.

COMMENCEMENT, PROSECUTION AND COMPLETION OF WORK

Work shall be commenced by the contractor within 20 days and shall be completed within 60 days after the execution of the contract on behalf of the Department of Indian Affairs.
The contractor shall at all times during the continuation of the contract, prosecute the work with such force and equipment as in the judgment of the engineer are sufficient to complete it within the specified time.

FAILURE TO COMPLETE THE WORK IN THE TIME AGREED UPON

LIQUIDATED LIABILITIES

Should the contractor fail to complete the work or any part thereof in the time agreed upon in the contract, or in such extra time as may have been allowed for delays, a deduction of $15.00 (Fifteen Dollars) per day will be made for each and every day, including Sundays and holidays, that the work remains uncompleted after the date agreed upon.

The said amounts are hereby agreed upon by the contractor as being liquidated liabilities for loss to the Department of Indian Affairs on account of expenses incurred by the Department due to the employment of engineers, inspectors and other employees after the expiration of the time for completion, and the amount due the Department of Indian Affairs will be deducted from any money due the contractor under this contract.

Sir:-

Re: Domestic Water Supply,
St. Joseph's Mission School.

With reference to the proposed domestic water supply system for St. Joseph's Mission school at 150-Mile House, tenders for which were called in the fall of 1920, I have to inform you that some question has arisen with reference to the available water supply from the springs which have been chosen as the source of supply for this project.

It appears that when Engineer Archibald made out the application for water he knew no name for the spring upon which application was made. It now develops that this spring is the source of a small creek known as Felker creek, upon which a water licence has been in existence since 1899 for irrigation purposes and while no water has been used under this licence for some years the holder of the licence, Mr. Felker, received on May 15, 1929, Conditional Licence No. 9961 from the Provincial Comptroller of Water Rights, this licence being a renewal of the old licence and the predecessor from the 20th December 1899, for 70 acre-feet of water from Felker creek for irrigation purposes on 50 acres of land on Lot 33, Group 1, Cariboo district.

Memorandum in duplicate by Mr. Archibald dated January 20th on this subject is enclosed for your reference, from which you will note there is sufficient water to satisfy both the Felker and the Indian school record provided the irrigation record allows a continuous flow during the irrigation period. This however we do not think is possible due to the small volume of water. An irrigation head is necessary and the 70 acre-feet held under licence will be drawn as irrigation needs demand. No rate of flow is specified in the conditional water licence.

The whole matter is now being investigated. The Comptroller of Water Rights is being consulted in the matter, and the Felker licence will be reviewed, following which we will be in a position to definitely determine if there is sufficient water available to satisfy both licences. The

Memorandum to Mr. Webb.

Re your memo of the 10th inst. respecting the objection of Mr. Felker to the diversion of water from the south branch of Felker Creek, for domestic use in St. Joseph's Mission.

At the time of investigation of the springs, requested in your letter of October 6, 1928, I was informed that they were nameless, and the pre-emptor's map in my possession at the time gave no name to the creek that they formed.

I found traces of old irrigation works from both spring channels, and on inquiry was informed that they had not been in operation for many years. This was evident from their condition. I was also told that the property formerly irrigated from these springs had long been abandoned. Water notices were accordingly posted, on 15th July, 1930, and application made for right to divert water from an unnamed spring, which is now recognized as the source of the south branch of Felker Creek, and which, according to my report of May 15, 1929, was estimated to have a minimum flow of 0.25 c.f.s., a flow still in excess of the requirements of St. Joseph's Mission.

Sir:

Re: Domestic Water Supply,
St. Joseph's Mission School.

Further to my letter of the 31st ult., with reference to proposed domestic water supply system for St. Joseph's Mission school at 150 Mile House, from a spring which is the main source of Felker creek, I have to inform you that the matter of water rights has been thoroughly reviewed.

I am informed by the Comptroller of Water Rights that the old water licence No. 2121 of H. A. Felker, taking precedence from 13th December, 1889, has been cancelled as it was imperfectly issued and a licence No. 9961 has been issued in lieu thereof, taking precedence from the same date. The purpose for which the water is to be used is irrigation and amounts to 70 acre-feet per annum.

The area and description of the irrigable land are an undefined 50 acres, comprising part of Lot 33, Group 1, Cariboo District. Under Board Order No. 3124, irrigation improvements are to be completed and water put to beneficial use on or before the 1st of November, 1931.

I have had conferences with Mr. Indian Commissioner Ditchburn and Rev. Father Rohr, head of the St. Joseph's Mission and both agree with me that it would not be advisable to proceed with the construction of the domestic water supply system for the school until we are assured of an adequate supply of water without any possibility of litigation with the holder of prior water right on Felker creek, which is the proposed source of supply for the Indian Residential School.

It is quite possible that the Felker interests will not do any work on their irrigation system this year. If no work is done by them before November 1, 1931, we will be in a position to ask for the cancellation of Conditional Licence No. 9961, due to non-compliance with conditions set out in Board Order No. 3124, and I feel confident that the Comptroller of Water

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit the following list of repairs and improvements necessary at the Cariboo Indian Residential School, and which the Principal states have been suggested by Mr. Barry the Schools Inspector, who will, I understand, recommend the expenditure. On a recent visit to the School, I went carefully into these matters, and there is no doubt but what they are very necessary.

Paint for implement shed and boy's washroom. This shed has never been painted and is more or less an eyesore amongst the painted buildings. The boy's washroom must be painted to keep it in a sanitary condition. Estimate: $30 plus paint.......................... $75.00

Cement floor for Dairy Room with a 30' drainage pipe. ........... $40.00

Firebricks around firebox in Laundry. This is a distinct fire hazard as at present used. A sheet iron stove is used to heat water in a tub receptacle for laundry purposes. The stove is broken in many places, and I would suggest replacing it with a brick firebox which can be built by the school staff. Estimate: brick & cement........ $25.00

Repair Laundry taps and pipes. The taps only require new washers. This should have been done by the staff long ago, and much water leakage thus prevented. Estimated cost .................................. $10.00

New grates for heating furnace (water tank in laundry). Three 12" grates required for No. 1000 furnace. No estimate obtainable.

New grates for furnaces in girls' building. Three 12" grates required for roller type for No. 1001 Economy Muffle furnace. No estimate.

LAUNDRY:

There are 24 wooden laundry tubs. These are also used for the boys' baths. The boys get a bath each week, and the girls have a bath once in two weeks. There is one small electric washing machine. This is used only by the Sisters. All the ordinary laundry work is done by hand. There is no proper drying system. The clothes, in winter, are hung in the Indian parlor, a room used for the reception of Indian visitors.

The water used in the laundry is heated in a small tank, placed on a rather primitive iron fire box. This box is worn out, and I recommend that it be discarded, and a proper fire box built of brick. This could be done at the school by the boys under instruction of one of the staff.

There is a Gurney hot water heater and a tank for the domestic hot water. The heater appears to be in very good condition, but the water in the tank will not heat. This is due, I believe, to the arrangement of pipes leading from the heater to the tank and to the tubs. These pipes appear to be to be very badly arranged. A qualified plumber should be employed to examine the system and to report if anything can be done. The Principal will try to remedy the poor condition noted, but if he fails help will be required.

The Principal is anxious to have a fairly large washing machine. He spoke of one of the semi rotary type. I have seen these machines work in a satisfactory manner with steam, and at Alberni Indian Residential School off an ordinary 115 Volt alternating circuit attached to a motor. The system at this school is a 32 Volt direct current, and would not have the sufficient amperage to work a large washing machine. The Delco at the Cariboo develops 3 K.W. To do the washing in a proper manner I believe that some sort of gas engine would be required. If the Department can see its way to do so, I would recommend that this matter be taken up with the school, and some form of fairly large washing machine be supplied. This is not a very urgent matter.

(Over)
EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR G. H. BARRY,
DATED JUNE 16, 1931, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE
CARIBOO INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

---

KITCHEN:

The kitchen is kept in spotless condition. The water front in the kitchen range needs to be taken out and cleaned. The pipes from it to the hot water tank require cleaning inside. At present the water does not heat properly in this tank. The boys, under direction of the staff, ought to be able to do the required work.

ICE HOUSE:

I should like to recommend that an ice house be approved for this school.

RECOMMENDATION:

I wish to recommend that a substantial building be constructed to contain two large classrooms, and two cloak rooms. If this be done the present classrooms could be used for dormitory accommodation for about 40 extra children. The building of the manual training shop was so successful that I see no reason why the school could not, through the manual training class, erect the classroom building mentioned above. It would not be in any sense a temporary building.

I understand that a number of children from the Chilcotin country are very anxious to attend the Cariboo Indian Residential School next term. Without the extra accommodation recommended above, there will be room for only about ten new children next term. The Chilcotin Indians are now anxious to send their children to the Cariboo. A number have applied through their missionary, Father Thomas.

I am assured by the Principal of the school that if the Department will expend $3000 on these new buildings, the Oblate Fathers will make up the difference, probably another $1000. I hope that the Department will give serious consideration to the above recommendation.
SANITARY CONDITIONS:

The dairy room requires a new cement floor. If this were put down so that there was a good slope to one corner and about 25 feet of drain pipe supplied, the floor could be properly washed out. The boys could do the necessary work if the material was supplied.

WATER SUPPLY:

This originates in the San Jose creek. A ditch from the creek takes water into an artificial lake known as Yellow Lake. This lake used to be a meadow, but was dammed by the Oblate Order years ago. The water from the lake is taken to the school in wooden pipes.

Yellow Lake is very shallow, from 1 to 3 feet deep, and a number of weeds grow in it. During the months of June, July and August, when the hot sun shines on the shallow water, the lake becomes renoid. It is then difficult to drink this water, but the school has no other option. In addition the fall from this lake to the school is so little that no pressure sufficient for fire fighting is generated.

About three miles from, and above, the school there are springs in the rock. This is known as the Felker spring. This spring gives abundance of excellent water, at present goes to waste. If this water was piped to the school, the fall to which is about 250 feet, there would be a pressure of about 100 pounds to the sq. inch in the pipes at the school. This would be excellent for fire fighting. I understand that this water has been filed on by other interests; but if it is not used in another year or so, the school might well be able to file on it. There are other springs nearer to the school which might well be investigated. I do not think they would produce as great a flow as the Felker springs, and if the water were piped to the school the pressure in the pipes would not be as great as 100 pounds to the sq. in.

Water is also brought from San Jose Creek direct. This comes through an open flume. This flume runs through the playground at the back of the girls' home. At this point it is about 2 ft. by 3 ft. and is sunk in the ground so that the top of the flume is level with the surface of the ground. This water is used for irrigation. The girls also bathe in the flume in the summer.

On several occasions, and twice this spring, the ice breaking up produced a jam in the flume. This caused the girls' basement to become flooded. I inquired why this water could not be used for domestic purposes, as it did not come through Yellow Lake. I am informed that the fall is so slight that there would be no pressure to force the water through the pipes.

I think that the whole question of a proper supply of water for fire fighting and domestic use may well be left over for another year.

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter #1-15 dated Feb. 24th.

Mr. Taylor, local Indian Agent, was here yesterday, and I think that he is satisfied that we are doing all we can for fire prevention. I was going to ask the Department for more fire extinguishers, but the Indian Agent believes that by placing what we have at more strategic points, we have enough. It was Colonel Pragnell who suggested the present number.

As the Department is aware, we have no fire hoses and no water with which to fight fire. We keep water in pails in the dormitories and other places but we can do nothing more as we have no pressure. On laundry days, we are frequently without water on the second stories of our various buildings. Moreover, at present we have a very limited supply of domestic water. The wooden pipes, which bring our water from Yellow Lake, an artificial reservoir, were laid twenty years ago (1917). They sprung at least two leaks recently with the result that a great deal of water is lost. We can do nothing in this regard until the ground thaws out. I fear that a great deal of expense will have to be incurred as the whole pipe line, after twenty years of service, may be in bad condition.

In so far as fire drills and a night watchman are concerned, there is nothing to worry about; the case is far different when it comes to our great lack of water.

I beg to remain yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Sir;

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st inst. relative to a request received by you from the Rev. Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School, for new laundry tubs.

There is no power laundry in operation at this School - the wooden laundry tubs which are ranged around the walls are, as the Principal states, also used by the girls as bath tubs, owing to lack of bath house facilities.

Hot and cold water is piped to the tubs which are at present made of wood, very old and now beyond repair. Galvanised iron laundry trays are required to put the laundry into proper workable condition and I have a quotation from Crane Limited, Vancouver B.C., as follows:

| Item                  | Quantity | Unit Price | Total   |
|-----------------------|----------|------------|---------|
| One 7 section tray    |          | $115.00    |         |
| One 5 ditto           |          | $4.00      |         |
| Two 6 @ $98.50 each   |          |            | $197.00 |
| **Total**             |          |            | $396.00 |

This quotation is F.O.B. the School station at 145 Mile but does not include waste pipe. For pipe and fitting another $25.00 may be allowed.

We have recently had the laundry overhauled and new fire grates and heating tank installed for the heater which supplies the hot water, and with the installation of these iron tubs the laundry will operate as efficiently as conditions in this old building will permit. I would recommend that consideration be given to the Rev. Principal's request if funds are available.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Dear Sir:

I beg to thank you for your Cheque # 5492 for $92.28. This was to pay for bricks, cement etc. to build a fire box in our laundry. The old one, a tin affair, was badly cracked, cracked open in places and was very dangerous especially in our case as our buildings are old and wooden and we have absolutely no water with which to fight fire.

This was the most needed but not the only alteration needed in the laundry. Mr. Taylor, local Indian Agent, has applied for new tubs at present we have old, leaky ones made out of wood. On Mondays they serve as laundry tubs and on Saturdays they become the children's bath tubs. I took our Provincial Superior, Father Grant,

To see the boys taking their bath. He admired their docility as the beds are so small that they have to draw their knees up to their chins to sit in the water. And at the same time they have to take care not to sit on the wooden planks at the bottom of the bed.

I know that the Department is hard put for money, but I trust that a way will be found to help us out in this matter. In order to keep down the Department's expenses, I have bought seven more bed jerseys and some blankets, eating the Oblate Fathers' money and have asked for no compensation for this or for expenses incurred in taking children to an eye specialist in hamilton. We are keen now in the neighborhood. I am glad to be able to say that the children are all well.

Again thanking you for your cheque.

Remain sincerely yours,

G. J. Wilson

Jan. 18th/32

Mr. Wm. C. Agar
Department of General Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ontario

Dear Sir:

It was very kind of you to answer the Children's Christmas letter. The telegram came just as we were about to begin our Christmas Concert and I read it and letters from the Archbishop of Vancouver and from Mr. Mitchell just before Father Grant gave out the presents.

I wish to thank you also for getting us the money to build a fire box in the laundry & to make other repairs. They were greatly needed. The former fire box, of tin, was old, cracked and had several holes in it. There was constant danger of fire even though we kept good watch. You can realize what a fire would mean here as the buildings are old and we have no water with which to fight fire.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6438, file 878-5, part 3)
Although the Department is hard pressed for money, I hope that Mr. Taylor, the local Indian agent, will be successful in getting us some funds. At present we have four wooden tubs divided into about six compartments, each about 2' x 2' x 2', in which the girls do the washing on Mondays and all the children, in turn, take their baths on Saturdays. These tubs are old and, though they have been repaired again and again, they leak. I had Dr. Grant watch some of the boys take a bath. He was amused to see how they could bath in the smallest tub—they had to draw their knees up to their chins and lean over where they bent at the waist in the bottom of the tub, so in the centre it projects a couple of inches. He said I had done well in asking for something better.

As I have pointed out to the Secretary, I have been at considerable expense to give the children what milk and butter they require. Although we own pure bred Jersey & some Holstein cows at no good deal, I did not ask any help in this matter from the Department. I have spent other money for the children and have asked nothing in return so as to help them down the Government expenses. I hope, however, that a way may be found to give us a few other things which we really need and which Mr. Taylor approves.

Again thanking you for the five-box and for lumber and other materials for necessary repairs.

I beg to remain,

Sincerely yours,

Geo. Johnson

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, relative to the improvements and repairs required at the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding approximately $70 in the purchase of lumber and material to erect a new outside toilet for the boys. You may arrange for the purchase, from a firm on the list to receive consideration, of the material required and have same forwarded to the school. It is understood that the labour will be carried out by the staff of the school without expense to the Department. After the material has been purchased you should forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

The Department will have no funds to provide new tubs, tile pipe and a cement floor for the laundry.

Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that on the 17th inst., I was at the Cariboo Indian Residential School when Mr. Inspector Barry made his school inspection. The following improvements and repairs will be suggested in his report to the Department and I would recommend that they be given every consideration as they are badly needed.

Now outside boy's toilet. The present building is in bad disrepair and is a health menace. Cost of local lumber and shingles to make new building in fresh location...$270.00

Double dressed coast spruce lumber for new laundry tubs. A regulation iron wash tub was not approved by the Department requiring local lumber. The present wooden tub is badly rotted and wastes much water and it is considered that new lumber tubs will answer the purpose. Lumber and vitrified tile pipe for laundry drainage will cost with freight...$195.00

New cement floor for laundry. The present floor is of lumber which is rotted and a breeding place for germs and a harbour for dirt. Owing to the floor still being also rotted another wooden floor is not advisable. Cement........$128.75

Total estimate net more than........$373.75

If funds are not available for this amount I would ask that the lumber for the boys' toilet be allowed as this is badly needed.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

H.E. Taylor

Dear Sir:

I beg to thank you for the set of new batteries which you kindly supplied for our Delco light plant. They came two weeks ago and they were set up immediately but I did not wish to write before I could assure you that they are very satisfactory. They were really needed as the old set was almost useless.

In this connection I think that I should point out that, according to what I am told, our Delco plant is too powerful for one set of batteries. Our engineer says that, if the plates in the old set were renewed, the life of the new set, which is guaranteed for five years, would be prolonged. I am going to submit this to Mr. Indian Agent Taylor so that he can investigate and advise you accordingly to what he finds.

Again thanking you for the batteries and for other favors,

I remain very truly yours,

Geo. Foster, O.M.

Sir;— I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th inst., re: voucher No.6480 for $273.80 for cost of Delco batteries supplied to the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

After I wrote to C.Lwain and Son of Kamloops, for a quotation on the batteries, I received a visit from the Delco salesman who explained the superiority of the new Ironclad type of batteries. This salesman apparently called at the request of C.Lwain and Son who are the Kamloops agents for the John Redden Co. of Vancouver. The order for the batteries was placed by letter with the C.Lwain firm in Kamloops, and they wired me when they were shipping the batteries to the School. Apparently C.Lwain & Son forwarded the order to their Vancouver people and collected their sales commission, and asked the John Redden Co. to do the actual shipping.

I should have forwarded a letter with the voucher, explaining the change in the name of the supplying firm, but it did not occur to me to do so.

I enclose a copy of my letter to C.Lwain & Son, ordering the batteries, which I trust makes the matter clear.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to advise you that I am informed by the Reverend Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School, that several bad breaks have occurred in the pipeline conveying their water supply to the school. These have been repaired but others are showing. The pipe has been in the ground over twenty-five years and it is evident that the whole pipeline requires renewing.

You will recall that, as a result of adverse analyses of the water used at the school, the Department intended to put in a new system utilizing water from another source. The proposed cost was high and funds have not been forthcoming to enable the scheme to be proceeded with.

The present supply of water comes from Yellow Lake, being conveyed through wooden piping for a distance of approximately 4,600 feet, to a storage reservoir, from whence, by gravity flow, it supplies the domestic requirements of the school.

There is a lot of offensive smelling vegetable matter in Yellow Lake and it has been necessary to clean out the storage reservoir at least once each month for the past two years. The whole pipeline must also be exceedingly foul, judging from the condition of the storage tank each time it is emptied. For drinking purposes water is now being packed by the pail from a small spring near the school, but there is a very limited supply available there. Fortunately the children have left for their summer holidays; otherwise a serious situation would have developed, probably necessitating the closing of the school.

Acting upon a suggestion of mine, the school authorities dug a pit beside Yellow Lake and it is claimed that the water will seep into this pit, cleaning itself out the process and rendering the water much more suitable for use. It will be of no avail to convey such purified water through the present foul pipeline even if the pipeline was in good condition. The school intend to enlarge the pit, and erect a sand and charcoal filter. If the resultant supply of water is then conveyed through new piping, the storage tank will remain clean and the buildings will be provided for the first time in many years with good water.

Unless the pipeline is renewed immediately there appears to be no guarantee that there will be a supply of water available for ordinary daily requirements in the school buildings.

I have obtained prices on 2" pipe from various Vancouver firms, and the cheapest and best type appears to be a solid-drawn steel pipe, coated and wrapped. The cost would be:

5,000 ft of 2" pipe @ $226.50 per M. . . .$1132.50

Labour for ditching and laying pipe
5,000 ft. at .20¢ per ft. $1000.00

Total $2132.50
The labour cost is based on $2.00 per day per man. The Rev. Principal states that he can obtain labour at $1.25 per day plus board which is estimated at $.75 per day per man.

I would be glad if the Department would advise me at their earliest convenience if they are prepared to render assistance to renew the pipeline. It may be possible to continue patching any leaks that develop, but there is always the possibility of the supply ceasing for several days at a time, especially in the winter time when locomotives and railway breaks could be much slower and more difficult. With 120 pupils in the school the cessation of the water supply would mean closing down operations.

I would not recommend the renewing of this pipeline unless there was a reasonable assurance of the water being cleaner and purer than heretofore, but I believe it will be.

The only alternative is the previous scheme which ran into many thousands of dollars.

The question of boring for well water has been gone into, as has also the possibility of lifting water from the San Jose Creek by means of a ram, but both schemes would be costly and there is no guarantee that a sufficient supply would always be available.

Dear Sir:

You may have been bothered recently with a number of tenders for water pipe to be supplied to this school. In case you haven't, I wish to inform you that, in so far as I remember, I have authorized no one to submit these tenders to you.

Some time ago we had serious trouble with our water system and, for three or four days, it was doubtful whether or not it could be repaired. We were finally able to patch it up at least for the time being and it is now in as good condition as it has been for some time. I believe that the Department is aware that this water system is not entirely satisfactory. In the first place, it has never had sufficient pressure to afford fire protection. In the second place, there is an evil smell and taste to the water especially in the warmer months. The old pipes are, I believe, saturated with this taste and odor besides being so old that they take a good deal of looking after. Fortunately, there is a small spring of good water nearby from which we are able to haul drinking water when necessary. The old wooden pipe, after being about 30 years in the ground, will soon need renewing unless another plan can be found. I think that a better and cheaper plan can and will be found before long.

My main object in writing is to assure you that the people who sent in tenders were authorized by me to send them only to the Indian agent and to myself. Mr. Taylor wished to have these estimates before taking the matter up with the Indian Department.

I walked for some miles through the country around the school in a search for possible sources of water supply. Under the heading of Water Supply (Continued) in my last report on this school, and in the portion of the last paragraph marked (2) I mentioned the existence of some small springs near the school. On my present tour of Inspection I found or rather had my attention drawn to some unnamed springs which are located nearer to the school than those mentioned in my last report.

These newly discovered springs are about 600 yards from the school buildings. They are located on the hillside quite close to and on the opposite side of the San Jose Creek to that occupied by the school buildings. This creek water comes from Lac Le Hache and does not flow through Yellow Lake. I am informed that the water of the creek itself is polluted during part of the year, as farmers place manure dams across the creek higher up, and thus use some of the water for irrigation.

I feel fairly confident that the springs I now draw the attention of the Department to are worthy of investigation. They should be dug out well above high water mark of the adjoining creek. A large cement tank here might be joined by a new pipe line to the existing large tank on the hillside above the school, and the water pumped into this tank so that it would flow by gravity through an existing pipe line to the school.

I recommend that the Department request a full report on the above mentioned source, and pumping proposal. I do not know the exact state of the existing pipe lines or of the present large tank on the hill over the school. I am suggesting this solution to the water problem at the school, as I feel confident that it could be made a success at a fraction of the sum suggested for the Felker Springs project. I am not doing more than this, as it may prove when examined by the Department's engineers to be an impossible project for some technical reason. I think it a good enough proposal to warrant the expense of investigation. I may say that I have had a very brief talk with Mr. Webb with regard to such a project, and am anxious that his advice should be sought in the matter.

Fire Protection:

The exit to the new fire escape from the new dormitory on the girls' side of the school had not been used when I visited the school. The door was still nailed or locked up, and the children for whom this escape was erected were making use of the old escape at the back of the convent. My objection to this is that these children have to cross one of the greatest fire hazards, the top of an open stair-way, on their way from the new dormitory to the old escape. This new escape should be placed in use at once. This has no doubt been done long ago, as I spoke strongly about it at the school, and later to Mr. Indian Agent Taylor. There is no expense attached to my recommendation. The Manual Training Class could have this door ready for use in a couple of hours.

There are now four wooden escapes, one being attached to the boys' building, and the remaining three being located at the rear of the convent.

The wooden platform at the back of the convent is in a very dangerous state of repair. There are broken planks and holes, and children might easily be hurt if they ventured on to this platform. I previously asked that this platform be repaired. The school does not appear to have the necessary lumber. Only rough boards would be required. The children are not permitted to venture on to this platform. I should like to see it replaced by one on which it would be safe to walk.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo regarding the repairs to the pipe line of the water supply system at the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

The School authorities were able to effect repairs to the existing line without any expense to the Department. There is, however, still the debatable question of the suitability of this water for domestic use in the School. Alternative proposals have been considered by myself and the resident principal to avoid altogether having to use this water, but so far, no scheme of moderate cost was available. I requested the School authorities to examine two different sources of supply but they have not yet decided if they could be used.

Another alternative would be to make the existing storage tank from the lake supply into a filter tank, and pump the water from it to an existing cement tank considerably higher on the hill above the buildings, thus obtaining a reserve for fire purposes and a clean water supply. I wish to be assured, however, that the scheme is workable before applying for any authority for expenditure.

An engineer's survey of the situation would possibly result in an estimate involving too much cost under present conditions, and I will further investigate the possibilities and report to you.

I do not want to ask for money to renew the present pipe-line if better water can be obtained for about the same cost from another source.

Your obedient servant,

H.E. Taylor

Sir:

I beg to refer to my letter of April 4th last in answer to yours of March 23rd last regarding the domestic water supply for the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

I have this date again taken up the matter with the Reverend Principal, but he has no definite suggestions as to what should be done.

Renewal of the existing pipe-line, as was suggested, will still entail the use of water from Yellow Lake which is partly stagnant during the hot months, and which is now used from storage tank which is cleaned out monthly to ensure fresh water.

A pipe line from San Jose river could be run to this tank which could be converted into a filter tank, and the water then pumped into second unused tank above the buildings. The water would have to be lifted from the river direct. The School authorities have water licenses on San Jose river which include a domestic water allotment. I would ask that an engineer of the Dominion Water Branch be instructed to examine this proposal and estimate the minimum cost.

I know of no other alternative satisfactory scheme, but do not feel competent to recommend any expenditure on such a scheme without an engineer's advice, as there are so many things to be taken into consideration to ensure a satisfactory delivery of water.

I do not think such an installation would be very expensive and the engineer could perhaps be requested to bear in mind the need for an economical estimate which would give an adequate water supply without any expensive works.

Sir:

Your letter of the 31st ultimo is acknowledged wherein you make a request from the Department of Indian Affairs for a report on the possibilities of a new domestic water supply system for the Cariboo Indian Residential School, Williams Lake Agency. It is noted the department have very limited funds available for this project and ask that consideration be given to the most economical system possible. This matter will be investigated at an early date and report submitted in due course.

A report on a water supply system for this school by Mr. F.R. Archibald dated May 13, 1929 was forwarded to Ottawa on June 7, 1929. This report outlined two schemes both of which required an enormous outlay of money. One from the San Jose river at an estimated cost of $16,000; the other from springs (Falker creek) three miles distant, at $25,500.

In 1930 tenders were called for the water supply system from springs (Falker creek) but the contract was never awarded due to the fact that some question of priority of water right developed on the springs from which the water was to be taken and we did not feel justified in proceeding without the Indian Department holding the first right on this limited supply. As the situation now stands the first right is held by Mr. Falker, the Indian Department's licence being second.

In any event the cost of bringing water three miles to the Indian School is high. On the other hand subsequent investigations have failed to disclose an favourable source of supply in closer proximity to the school. We will however keep the matter looked into as stated above and report made, having in mind that funds are very limited at the present time.

You might let me know how much money the Department has available for this project.

Sir:

St. Joseph's Mission School

Water Supply

As requested I made an investigation of the available source for a suitable supply of water for domestic use for the above institution and wish to submit as follows:

Present Source of Supply.

The present source of domestic supply is from Yellow Lake, which prior to 1881 was a slough. This slough was found to be conveniently situated and was used for irrigation purposes by diverting the San Jose River into it. Yellow Lake was not used however for domestic purposes until 1912 when a spring which up to that time had been the source of supply went dry, and a new pipe line was laid from Yellow Lake to the school.

In 1922 the low ground between Yellow Lake and Trout Lake broke away. A dyke was then constructed across the east end of what is now Trout Lake and the diversion ditch from San Jose River brought into it.

Yellow Lake is situated at an elevation of about 50 feet above the school site. It is about 15 acres in extent and has a maximum depth in excess of 13 feet. A flow of about 4 cubic feet per second normally takes place from the San Jose River through the lake and when not used for irrigation purposes finds its way back to the river.

The water system consists of a two inch wood-stave pipeline from Yellow Lake to a small tank of about
2000 gals. capacity near the school buildings from which distribution is made to various points of use. Service pressure varying from 5 to 15 pounds. There is no provision for fire service.

Prospective Sources of Supply.

The available sources of supply are:

1.- San Jose River or Yellow Lake
2.- Felker Spring
3.- Ground water.

The first and last only of these sources were examined by me as Felker Spring is already the subject of a report by Mr. F. R. Archibald dated May 13, 1929, who estimated the cost of developing that source at approximately $29,000.00.

The San Jose River water diverted either directly from the river or by way of Yellow Lake would provide an abundant supply of water for all uses of the school, although the water in its natural state is of poor quality, and is sometimes unfit for human consumption. Material improvement could be effected by filtration, and if necessary it could be sterilized.

Regarding a supply from below ground, several small springs show along the bank of the San Jose River in the vicinity of the school. It is probable their source is irrigation water. The available ground supply appears to be limited although the quality as represented by the sample analyzed is fair. See Appendix IA.

I have accordingly made up estimates of the cost of developing the above mentioned sources of supply which are attached hereto - Appendix #2.
School Requirements:

The domestic requirements of St. Joseph's school are probably the lowest per capita of any of the residential schools in the province, being about 25 gals per day. This is in part due to the poor quality of the water, but more particularly to the limited facilities of the schools. In addition to about 2,500 gals per day for domestic use an amount of about 500 gals per day is necessary for stock watering.

Ground Water Development:

The accompanying plan shows a possible development of a small spring on the bank of the San Jose River, the flow of which at the time of my visit in July was six gals per minute. I have been informed that this spring has been flowing for at least 10 years, which would indicate that it was of a fairly permanent character, as during the past ten years some of the driest periods on record have been experienced in that locality. However as it is probable the source is from irrigation water, the supply should continue so long as irrigation is carried on in that vicinity. While it might be possible to secure a ground water supply from wells closer to the school, it is not to be considered, due to the possibility of contamination.

Owing to the situation of the spring mentioned, care would be necessary in developing it for use in order to exclude the San Jose River at freshet period. Protection against extremely cold winter conditions would be necessary for pumping equipment as it is not possible to provide an underground pump house at the spring.

The estimated cost of developing the spring to provide for domestic requirements, exclusive of laundry, flush toilets,
outbuildings, etc., is $2,625.00.

The system would comprise a 1250 gal. pressure tank with pump equipment, capable of supplying approximately 12 gal. per minute from a collecting well at the spring of about 800 gals. capacity. The distribution system would parallel the present system and supply all services in the school buildings except those noted, which would be served from the present system so long as it is possible to keep it in repair.

The system outlined above while it would fill the immediate requirements for a supply of water of fair quality for domestic purposes would not appear to completely solve the problem in regard to this school, as in all probability the present pipe line from Yellow Lake would have to be renewed in the course of a year or two.

San Jose River Supply:

To develop a water supply system for St. Joseph Mission from the above source for domestic purposes only would require an ultimate outlay of $11,059.00 and to provide for fire protection as well would require approximately $20,220.00 by making use of Yellow Lake. The cost of diverting directly from the San Jose River would exceed these figures by a substantial amount and would not be advantageous in any way.

The system contemplated would require the renewal of the present two inch pipe line from Yellow Lake, now almost at the end of its life, by a three inch pipe line capable of delivering a supply of 25 gals per minute to two pressure filters, connected for a series or parallel operation and delivering to a storage reservoir of 7,500 gals capacity. Distribution to points of use to be made through the present
system until such time as the existing pipe is renewed. It would be necessary to improve the condition of Yellow Lake materially if it is to be used for the purpose of a water supply.

It is suggested in this connection that Yellow Lake be separated from Trout Lake and a new ditch constructed to Yellow Lake from the San Jose River, also that the vegetation in Yellow Lake for the greater part should be removed and the lake treated occasionally for algae. I have been informed that since the two lakes have been joined the growth of weeds in Yellow Lake has increased considerably as has also the unpleasantness of taste and odor of the water.

As there does not appear to be facilities for drawing off the lake near the bottom, I would suggest that a 12 inch culvert be installed at a depth of 6 feet or greater if possible, and that all irrigation and excess water be drawn down through it in order to prevent present stagnant condition, and reduce the percentage of decayed vegetable matter in the water used.

Also that the intake pipe be extended to a distance of 250 feet into the lake when being renewed.

The improvements suggested may be carried out as funds become available, and need not all be considered an immediate necessity. It would be desirable to carry out a program of development in the following order.

1.- Filter system and storage tank.
2.- Separating the lakes, new diversion ditch, cleaning and treating.
3.- Renewing intake pipe and provide deep draw off culvert.
4.- Renewal of pipe line lake to school.

Should it not be possible to keep the pipe line in repair until such time as replacement can be made it might be necessary
to interchange 3 and 2 in order of precedence.

**Felker Spring:**

I am informed by the Mission School authorities that the prior licensees on Felker Spring is prepared to relinquish priority to the school to the extent of their domestic requirements should the school be prepared to develop that source of supply.

**Fire Protection:**

It is not possible to provide a supply of water in sufficient volume (500 g.p.m.) for fire protection purpose from any other source in the immediate locality than the San Jose River. As the pressure head provided by Yellow Lake is insufficient for purposes of fire protection, it will be necessary to install a booster pump on the fire line to produce the necessary pressure.

The cost of providing a fire protection service is estimated at $13,075.00 if installed separately and if provided in conjunction with the domestic water supply from the same source $9,165.00.

This installation could be carried out as an extension of the suggested progressive development for the domestic supply, the additional outlay for the third step would be $2,930.00 or a total of $6,650. for installation of the larger pipeline from Yellow Lake. The fourth step would be the addition of booster pump and fire stations at a cost of $6,425.00

**Conclusions:**

While the development of the spring water supply may be carried out at a minimum cost and with some assurance that it is of fair quality, the supply is definitely limited, although it may reasonably be assumed that the source
is irrigation water, there is no assurance that the flow may not decrease beyond the point of usefulness at some time during the year.

On the other hand should the spring continue to flow at its present rate, all of the requirements of the school would have to be pumped from this source within a year or two at a probable cost of $20.00 to $25.00 per month as the renewal of the pipeline from Yellow Lake would not likely be undertaken.

The San Jose River is an unfailing source of supply, even in the driest years experienced there has not been a shortage of water from Yellow Lake for domestic purposes. The quality of the water however is definitely not good although it can be improved by treatment to compare favorably with that from the spring above referred to.

Recommendation:

I am of the opinion that the present source of supply, the San Jose River by way of Yellow Lake is most likely to provide a permanent supply of water for use of the schools, and for that reason should be developed as means become available.

Your obedient servant,

W. C. Warren

Dear Sir:

I am pleased to enclose for your reference report in duplicate by Mr. Warren, August 21st, 1935 on St. Joseph's Mission School Water Supply.

From the report it is evident that no satisfactory water service can be furnished the school for the $2,500.00 which is at present available. As a temporary measure only the spring referred to may be tapped, but in view of the uncertainty of the supply from this source I am loathe to recommend it.

Undoubtedly Felker Creek would give the most satisfactory water supply but it seems to me its cost is prohibitive, on the other hand it is estimated a satisfactory supply from Yellow Lake will cost something over $20,000.00.

It is unfortunate that there is no satisfactory water supply in close proximity to this institution, but if the school is to remain in its present site for the next 10 or 15 years the department would be well advised to develop a satisfactory water supply system from the San Jose River or Felker Creek even though the cost is expensive relative to the value of the buildings at the institution.

Copies of this report are today being forwarded to Ottawa.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Urgent requests have been made by the Indian Agent and the Principal of the School that steps be taken to carry out improvements to the domestic water system at the Cariboo Indian Residential School, Williams Lake Agency, (Electoral District of Cariboo) B.C.

The Dominion Water Power Branch was requested to have an engineer visit the school and report. The report of the engineer has now been received. He states that the installing of a fully adequate system for the domestic water supply and also for fire protection would cost approximately $15,000. He states, however, a sufficient supply for domestic purposes, exclusive of laundry, flush toilets and outbuildings, can be obtained from a small spring, at a distance of 1250 ft. from the school, and that this supply would meet the immediate requirements for several years. He estimates the cost of supplying material, equipment and labour to be approximately $2,625.

The sum of $2,500 is provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, to improve the water supply at this school. As this work should be carried out this fall, before the extreme cold weather sets in, I would recommend that I approve of the expenditure required - approximately $2,625 - and that the work be carried out by the Dominion Water Power Branch, under the supervision of their engineer.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

Re: Department of Indian Affairs Equipment.

On May 1st last I forwarded a copy of a letter from Fernie Brothers, Kamloops, dated April 27, 1935, in which they offered $100 for the pneumatic storage tank at the Kamloops Industrial School. Your letter of May 16th advising that the disposal of the tank was being turned over to Col. R.H. Beer, Dominion Salvage Officer, was received. Since that time we have heard nothing in the matter although we wrote Fernie Brothers advising them of what had taken place and suggesting that they get in touch with us in the course of a week or so if they did not hear from Col. Beer.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Urgent requests have been made by the Indian Agent and the Principal of the School that steps be taken to carry out improvements to the domestic water system at the Cariboo Indian Residential School, Williams Lake Agency, (Electoral District of Cariboo) B.C.

The Dominion Water Power Branch was requested to have an engineer visit the school and report. The report of the engineer has now been received. He states that the installing of a fully adequate system for the domestic water supply and also for fire protection would cost approximately $12,000. He states, however, a sufficient supply for domestic purposes, exclusive of laundry, flush toilets and outbuildings, can be obtained from a small spring, at a distance of 1500 ft. from the school, and that this supply would meet the immediate requirements for several years. He estimates the cost of supplying material, equipment and labour to be approximately $2,625.

The sum of $2,500 is provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, to improve the water supply at this school. As this work should be carried out this fall, before the extreme cold weather sets in, I would recommend that you approve of the expenditure required - approximately $2,625 - and that the work be carried out by the Dominion Water Power Branch, under the supervision of their engineer.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

The Very Reverend Father Scannell has written to me saying that you wish me to write to you in connection with the new domestic water system which the Department has kindly agreed to install in this school. First, however, I wish to thank you for Mr. J.M. Bennett's "Catechetics" and for the donation towards painting some of the buildings. You suggested that some inside painting be done. I am pleased to report that, thanks to your suggestion and the cheque, the boys' dormitory, toilet, playroom and clockroom look much cleaner and brighter. The exterior of the manual training shop also was painted.

Mr. Warren, the Engineer, sent by the Department, spent about a week here and went into the question thoroughly. I have not a copy of his report and, so, cannot go into it thoroughly. Mr. Indian Agent Taylor lent me his copy and I believe that it, the report, is accurate. I am not, however, convinced that the water now used is as dangerous as suggested. I have used it for over four years and have felt no ill effects. Two or three years ago, when the weather was very warm in the summer and the water low, the smell and the taste of the water were unbearable. Since then, in the warm months, the taste and the smell have been very unpleasant but, except for a week or two, bearable. However, on several occasions, this water has been analyzed by the Provincial Analyst and has been pronounced unfit for human consumption so that if any illness or epidemic were occasioned by the use of this water the school and, perhaps, the Department might be held responsible. A new water supply, for domestic purposes, is, therefore, at least highly advisable.
But the Indian Department knows all this and appreciated it to the extent that for the last five or six years it has been seeking a solution to the problem. Five or six years ago it sent engineers upon whose recommendation it had $25,000 appropriated to install a new system and that system would have been installed had not Mr Felker refused to give up his first rights on the source of supply. (May I here remark that three or four years ago Mr Felker agreed to give up his rights in our favor? Unfortunately the Department had no longer the funds to avail itself of Mr Felker's offer). Quite recently, the Department sent an engineer and was prepared to install a new domestic water supply system. Why oppose it?

I did not oppose it. After Mr Warren's survey, things moved more quickly than I had anticipated and one morning Mr Indian Agent Taylor informed me, as did also a letter, that the work was to begin, at least as I understood it, immediately. I telegraphed to my Superior asking him to have the work held up until he received a letter from me. In this letter I said that the proposed work called for the installation of an engine and a reservoir in an O.M.A.T. building besides the installation of pipes, etc., in other Oblate buildings. I believed that I needed his permission for this. I also put both sides of the question before him. The ultimate solution is the more costly plan of Mr Warren—the bringing of the water through purifiers, from Yellow Lake or from the San Jose river. As Mr Warren pointed out, the source he suggested would supply only domestic water (and he suggested this only as a second best) so that the most of the water would still have to come from Yellow Lake. He pointed out, furthermore, that the pipes from Yellow Lake, which are wooden and about 30 years old and, in the past 3 years, have broken so repeatedly that they cannot last more than a year or two longer—he pointed out that these pipes would in all likelihood have to be replaced next year or the following year and he added that, on that account, unless the School would not be rebuilt within ten or fifteen years (and it would then be built, quite likely, on another location) it would be better to install the costlier system which would be
cheaper in the long run, I might add that the plan recently adopted affords no fire protection. I cannot speak officially but I have reason to believe that, if the Department considered a new school, very satisfactory arrangements with regard to land would be made.

To sum up, the costlier scheme or the bringing of the water from the spring contemplated about six years ago would be the best solution. That would cost a great deal but would be the better solution if the money is available. If it is not, then, as a second best, the cheaper plan should be followed. So far, no evil effects have been felt, except for the taste and the odor, from the present source but this source has been condemned by the Provincial Analyst to whom the engineers and, under instructions, I believe, Inspector Barry sent samples.

As I am more than busy, I would ask you to excuse the haste with which this has had to be written.

Very truly yours,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt this date of your telegram of the 4th inst., requesting particulars regarding the request of the Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School for a new Delco Lighting plant complete with an extra set of batteries.

In February last the Department paid for a new armature which was supplied for the present lighting plant by Messrs. Boulthbee Ltd. of Vancouver, that firm being then the agents for Delco equipment. The cost of this armature was $120.00 as per my Voucher No. 7397.

In November last the Principal of the school informed me that this armature was defective and that the lighting plant was operating unsatisfactorily. I ascertained that Messrs. Boulthbee Ltd. has given up their Delco agency and that it had been taken over by the MacKinnon Sales & Service Ltd. of Vancouver, B.C.

I took up with this firm the matter of replacing the allegedly defective armature and they stated that it was probably burnt out owing to electrical faults in the switchboard of the Delco plant. They offered to send a man up from Vancouver to check over the plant for the sum of $60.00 plus cost of any necessary parts.

As I had no authority to incur this expense I referred the matter to the School Principal who sent for the repair man. After examination the repair man reported that the armature supplied by Boulthbee Ltd. was defective and that a new one also some other parts, and the Principal paid him $120.00 and asked me to submit this account to the Department for payment. I have held this account pending a possible adjustment with Boulthbee Ltd. who, I think, should make a rebate for the defective armature purchased by the Department. I am still corresponding with them.

The service man from MacKinnon Sales and Service recommended that, in view of the age of the plant, which is fifteen years, that a new automatic plant be installed and the present one kept for emergency. He stated that there was no guarantee that the plant would continue to operate satisfactory as many parts were worn out and were in need of replacing.

Shortly afterwards the Principal advised me that the cylinder head in the plant engine was cracked and might cease to function at any time. Another engine was borrowed for a while but had to be returned.

The present plant was purchased by the Oblate Order but the Principal stated that he had no funds to replace it and requested me to ascertain if the Department could supply a new plant.

A quotation was submitted by MacKinnon Sales & Service as follows:

- A 2 kilo 32 volt Model 20 A.B.3 Delco Lighting Plant at $960.00 F.O.B. the School.
- A set of Ironclad Batteries for $85.00.

This plant is made in the U.S.A. and if admitted into Canada as a farm machine there would be a reduction of $100.00.
on the lighting plant and $35.00 on the batteries.

Thus the total cost would be either $1241.00 or $1026.00.

The Principal states that the fire hazard is greatly increased by having to use lamps and matches when the light fails. At the time of writing, the plant is still working but the Principal advises me that the cylinder head is only just hanging together and that the engine valves are also going and that the plant may quit at any time. I understand that the MacKinnon Sales & Service of Vancouver are the British Columbia distributors for Delco plants and that any sales would go through them.

Your obedient servant,
