Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt this date of your telegram of the 4th inst., requesting particulars regarding the request of the Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School for a new Delco lighting plant complete with an extra set of batteries.

In February last the Department paid for a new armature which was supplied for the present lighting plant by Messrs. Boultbee Ltd. of Vancouver, that firm being then the agents for Delco equipment. The cost of this armature was $100.00 as per my Voucher No.7387.

In November last the Principal of the school informed me that this armature was defective and that the lighting plant was operating unsatisfactorily. I ascertained that Messrs Boultbee Ltd. has given up their Delco agency and that it had been taken over by the MacKinnon Sales & Service Ltd. of Vancouver, B.C.

I took up with this firm the matter of replacing the allegedly defective armature and they replied that it was probably burnt out owing to electrical faults in the switchboard of the Delco plant. They offered to send a man up from Vancouver to check over the plant for the sum of $40.00 plus cost of any necessary parts.

As I had no authority to incur this expense I referred the matter to the School Principal who sent for the repair man. After examination the repair man reported that the armature supplied by Boultbee Ltd. was defective. He put in a new one also some other parts, and the Principal paid him $125.40 and asked me to submit this account to the Department for payment. I have held this account pending a possibly adjustment of Boultbee Ltd., who, I think, should make a rebate on the defective armature purchased by the Department. I am writing corresponding with them.

The advice I received from MacKinnon Sales & Service recommended that in view of the age of the plant, which is fifteen years, that a new automatic plant be installed and the present one kept for emergency. He stated that there was no guarantee that the plant would continue to operate satisfactorily as many parts were worn out and were not worth replacing.

Shortly afterwards the Principal advised me that the cylinder head in the plant engine was cracked and might cease to function at any time. Another engine was borrowed for a while but had to be returned.

The present plant was purchased by the Oblate Order but the Principal stated that he had no funds to replace it and requested me to ascertain if the Department could supply a new plant.

A quotation was submitted by MacKinnon Sales & Service as follows:

- A 2 kilo 32 volt Model 20 A.B.3 Delco Lighting Plant at $960.00 F.O.B. the School.
- A set of Ironclad Batteries for $211.00.

This plant is made in the U.S.A. and if admitted into Canada as a farm machine there would be a reduction of $120.00.
on the lighting plant and $35.00 on the batteries.

Thus the total cost would be either $1241.00 or $1026.00.

The Principal states that the fire hazard is greatly increased by having to use lamps and candles when the light fails. At the time of writing, the plant is still working but the Principal advises me that the cylinder head is only just hanging together and that the engine valves are also going and that the plant may quit at any time.

I understand that the MacKinnon Sales & Service of Vancouver are the British Columbia distributors for Delco plants and that any sales would go through them.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I think it my duty to call your attention to our pressing need of a new Delco plant. You may recall that, owing to its having outlived its natural life by five years, the present plant broke down twice last Fall and caused great inconvenience to say nothing of the heavy costs for repairs which the Department was kind enough to meet. The mechanic, finally sent by the Vancouver Delco Agents, warned us that, although he had done his best, the plant was an old one and that we might expect more trouble at any time.

As the Delco Agents have only one service man for B.C., it was ten days after our trouble that we were able to get him. We were lucky at that as he was about to start out on a three months tour of the southern part of the Province. During that time we were without electric light and had to use lamps and candles. (We were able to borrow a generator but it proved too small.) As we are in a valley and the hill to the east is high, the classes starting at 4 p.m., had soon to be called off as the strain was too much on the pupils' eyes. The kitchen and other departments also suffered. The greatest cause of worry, however, was the fire hazard. Naturally, we exercised the greatest caution but the danger was there as our 120 pupils are only children after all and an accident might easily have happened during those ten days. The danger is very great here as our buildings are old, dry frame buildings and, except for water buckets...
and fire extinguishers, we have no fire protection. The Department recognized this fact when, in 1930, it had $25,000.00 appropriated for the installation of a water system as this was the only system that would give us sufficient pressure for fire hoses. (As you may be aware, this system was not installed because the man who had water rights on the source of supply refused to give them up at the time. Shortly after my coming here, I made representations to him, stressing the fire hazard, and he consented to give up his rights in our favor, free of charge, but the money had then reverted to the Treasury).

I do not think it necessary to say more except that I was not the only one to get very little rest during those ten days. Especially as I have done my best to ask for as little as possible, I would ask you to do your utmost to get a new Delco plant for us out of the money which was appropriated for the installation of the domestic water system surveyed and suggested by the Engineer whom the Department sent here last Fall. I know that the Department is at least as anxious as I am to do its utmost to avoid a holocaust in any Indian school.

Mr. Indian Agent Taylor, whom I am going to ask to support my request, has, I believe, the quotations on a Delco plant. If I am not mistaken it is about $800.00. I do not know whether or not this includes batteries. If the Department could have the tax taken off, a saving would be made. The Delco man said that there was no tax on Delcos for farm use. Our plant is so old that only $90.00 was offered for it on a "trade-in". In that case, it might be well to keep it for emergencies, spare parts, etc.

When Mr. Phelan was here, he visited everything on the place. I do not know whether he remembers our laundry. If he does, he will back me up in my statement that there is probably not another like it in any Indian School. In the first place, we have no machinery and I am glad of that as the fact that the girls have to do all the washing by hand is an excel-
lent training for their lives at home. With this training, washing at home will not seem so hard and the girls will do it regularly as the former schoolgirls now do it on their reserves. However, the floor, being rotten in places, the room dark, somewhat small and not very well ventilated, the plumbing requiring frequent repairs, I decided (and Mr Phelan agreed with me) that all the money appropriated for repairs to the school would be spent on a new laundry. As there were only $400.00 to spend, we were unable to do more than put up the building although nothing was paid out in wages as the boys did the work as part of their manual training. Shingles or siding must still be bought for the outside of the walls, cement for the floor, bricks for the chimney and plumbing fixtures. Besides that, new tubs are required. Metal ones would be best but wooden ones would cost less. Could you please try your best to have the balance of the $2500.00 spent on finishing the laundry which will be big enough, well lighted and properly ventilated? This would greatly lessen the laundry work and, perhaps, benefit the children's health. If Mr Phelan remembers what he saw, he will assure you that I am not exaggerating.

I am pleased to say that things have gone on well this year. Inspector Barry said that he was satisfied. I am pleased to say that the former school children are doing well and show that they have benefited by their stay here. One of them broke into a liquor store but he is one of those whom I sent away.

Thanking you for former favors,

I remain yours truly,

[Signature]

P.S. The following taken from a letter of Mr. Chelcotein to his boys here, might interest you: "I didn't make much money this year—just enough to buy food for them. If you are lucky to be in school where you get plenty to eat, if you were home you would be hungry many days."

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th inst., with reference to the provision of a new Delco Lighting Plant for the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

The present plant is still functioning although the Principal advises me that it may fail at any time, but if it carries on for the remainder of the winter it may last for some months.

When the matter of a new plant was first discussed I asked the Principal if it could not be provided by the church authorities, in view of the fact that they own the property. The Principal stated that he was operating at a loss and could not find the money.

The school operates an extensive ranch in connection, for which much of the labour is provided free by the school pupils, and I have often thought that they should be in a position to provide many of the things for which we are continually asked.

I hesitated to express an opinion in this regard in the absence of any definite knowledge of the Departmental policy, and in view of the fact that in the past assistance has always been most generously given.

There is undoubtedly a growing tendency for the school to look to the Department for every need, and if it is not provided by us, ways would doubtless be found to procure.

The Rev. Father Forbes, the principal, is now on the prairies and may go to Ottawa, in which case the matter might be taken up with him in person.

Your obedient servant,

Sir;

I beg to advise that the Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School reports that the pipeline from Yellow Lake to the school storage tank, upon which the present water supply for the school depends, broke down recently. Although it has been temporarily patched up, it is considered undesirable, and there is a prospect of the school being deprived of water for domestic purposes at any time.

A report of the Dominion Water Bureau, dated August 21st, 1935, and prepared by Mr. W. C. Warren, deals with the question of water supply for this school, including the matter of renewing the pipeline in question.

Money was voted last year to install a drinking supply system, as recommended by Mr. Warren, from springs on San Jose river, at an estimated cost of $2325.00. Owing to some confusion regarding an alternative scheme proposed, I believe, by the School Principal, the work was not proceeded with, and the supply from Yellow Lake has been used up to the present time.

The drinking supply system mentioned above would not provide sufficient water for laundry and other domestic uses, and therefore would not solve the whole water supply question, as noted by Mr. Warren on page 4 of his report, where he also observes that in all probability the present pipe line from Yellow Lake would have to be renewed in the course of a year or two.

Mr. Warren estimates the cost of a domestic supply from Yellow Lake at $11,055.00. This provides for new storage tank, filters, new pipe etc.

The only other alternative appears to be the renewing of the present pipeline to the present storage tank, utilizing the existing pipe line, and cleaning out and chlorinating the tank now in use, at regular intervals. This has not been estimated upon by an engineer. The Principal considers that, with Indian labour, he could replace the same for approximately $2500.00.

As stated, the use of the springs on San Jose river would not give the School water for all domestic purposes, so that the pipeline from Yellow Lake would need replacing in any case. If it is renewed so as to ensure a supply of water, the matter of new storage tank, filters, etc., could be dealt with as money became available.

It would, of course, be more desirable to carry out the full scheme from Yellow Lake, as proposed by Mr. Warren, but if the amount required is not available this year, something will need to be done without delay, to ensure water being available when the school returns in September.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, September 5, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th ultimo, regarding the water supply system at the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that, after giving the matter every consideration, it will not be found possible to obtain any funds, from our appropriation for the present fiscal year, either to provide a water supply for domestic purposes or to install the necessary piping, etc., in securing an adequate supply of water for all school purposes. I would point out that this school is the property of the Church authorities. The Department feels that they should accept responsibility for supplying and installing the water supply system for the school. In any event, we will be unable to provide any funds to improve the water situation at this school during the present fiscal year.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I beg to refer to the report of Dr. A.L. McQuarrie, the Asst. Director of Medical Services for B.C., under date of the 16th inst. and to that part of the report which deals with the latrines in the boys section of the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

When this new outside latrine was built, with the assistance of the Department for lumber used, it was anticipated that the trench would be kept properly flushed out during the summer months. This was not done during the last summer vacation, with the result that it was in very unsanitary condition when viewed by Dr. McQuarrie.

Owing to the extreme cold weather in the winter time, flush toilets would not be practical. The alternatives are a proper septic tank or very deep earth pits which could be filled in when full up, and the building moved to another location.

I have discussed the matter with the school Principal who is prepared to dig a septic tank. If this is done, the accumulated matter which will freeze in the pit during the winter months, would have to be flushed down a large pipe inlet into the septic tank in the spring. This may present difficulties. In looking at them I also discussed the matter, thinking that they could be dug ten or twelve feet under the latrine building would be sufficiently dark to prevent any danger from flies during the warm weather. As an additional precaution, covers could be hinged to the seats.

I will discuss these proposals further with the Principal with a view to having one or the other system installed before freeze up.

This school is handicapped by not having the water and interior facilities for proper flush toilets. In the girls quarters there is a septic tank outlet which functions satisfactorily, but it has been found easier to keep things sanitary in the girls buildings than in the boys.

Memorandum:

I am returning herewith the memorandum to you of the second instant from the Acting Director of Indian Affairs relative to necessary repairs to the pipeline which provides water to the Cariboo Indian Residential School. In this memorandum the Acting Director mentions that according to an estimate received in 1935, it would have cost approximately $2,600 to replace the present pipeline with new iron pipe and place the new pipe 4 feet underground for the approximate distance of a mile.

This matter has been looked into by our Engineering and Construction Service and the Indian Affairs Branch has evidently misunderstood the application of this estimate. The figure of $2,600 had nothing to do with replacement of existing pipe but merely covered the cost of a new auxiliary gravity system from a spring to augment the existing domestic supply.

Mr. Warren's estimate on replacing the existing 2" pipe of the present system with new 3" wood stave pipe is $3,720. This provides for a length of approximately 4,500 feet. This will effect immediate repairs to the domestic supply, it being understood that the 2" pipe has practically collapsed in several sections.

Dr. Charles Camsell, C.M.G.,
Deputy Minister of Mines and Resources.
Storage in Yellow Lake, filtration of water and new intake. The estimated cost of this additional work is placed by Mr. Warren at $11,055.

It should also be pointed out that the 3" wooden pipe replacement will not, of course, provide fire protection for the School. (The present line does not provide fire protection.) Due to the low head between the source of supply and the School, an 8" pipeline would be required to carry enough water for fire-fighting purposes and a booster pump would have to be installed. The cost of the 8" pipeline would be about $6,300.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

For the past three or four years, the pipeline which conducts the water from the source of supply to the Cariboo Indian Residential School has been giving considerable trouble. This pipeline was originally installed about 30 years ago. Frequent repairs have been made, but recent reports indicate that, in order to insure a reasonably adequate water supply for the Cariboo Indian Residential School, it will be necessary to replace the pipeline.

The present pipeline is 4 feet underground and nearly one mile long. It will be necessary to dig up the old pipeline and replace with new iron pipe. The cost of this work will be approximately $2,600.00, which was an estimate given in 1935 by Mr. Warren, of the Dominion Water Power Branch.

If the Department allows the sum of $2,000.00, the management of the Cariboo Residential School is prepared to pay the balance. All work will be done by Indians, some of whom are on relief at present, but, if given work in this way, can be removed from the relief list.

There is available, in our appropriation for the current fiscal year, a sum of $2,000.00 which could be used for this purpose, and I would appreciate receiving your approval to authorize the work proceeding. It is important that it should be commenced immediately.

The Cariboo Indian Residential School is in the electoral district of Cariboo, B.C.

Acting Director of Indian Affairs

BRITISH COLUMBIA May 14th, 1937

The Very Reverend Father Provincial,
Ottawa, Ont.

Very Reverend and Dear Father:

Our water pipe line between Yellow Lake and the reservoir, a distance of about 4800 feet, has burst or has been plugged and, although I have had three or four working on it since last Saturday, the trouble has not been found and, from this source, we have had no water in the School for almost a week. We can carry on for about a month as the irrigation water has been piped to our buildings but after about June 15th, when the irrigation water will have to be turned off, we shall have no water and will, I think, have to close the School unless the trouble is located and the pipe repaired or the pipeline renewed.

Unless we are very fortunate, we may have to dig up a great deal of the pipeline before locating the trouble. If it were a leak and if it happened in the dry season, there would be signs to go by. As it is, the land is sopping wet in many places owing to irrigation and other causes. If we had to dig up most of or all the pipeline, it would pay, in the long run, to put in a new pipeline as the present one is, I believe, about 30 years old and, being wooden, is just about rotten.

On and off, since I came here over six years ago, this pipeline has been giving trouble but up until now we have been able to find the trouble and remedy it. I have called this matter to the attention of the Indian Department on several occasions and, a couple of years ago, they were good enough to have Mr Warren survey and report upon the matter as well as upon a less costly scheme. The Department was willing, I believe, to go forward with the less costly scheme but I did not think it advisable. In the first place, this scheme would have given us only enough water for domestic purposes but none for the laundry, baths, toi-

Cariboo Indian School Station P.G.E.

BRITISH COLUMBIA

Let us, etc., and I did not feel justified in having the Department spend this money (about $2500.00, I think) when I foresaw that the necessity in which, sooner or later, we should be of asking to have the pipeline from Yellow Lake renewed. There were indications of trouble less than a year ago and I asked Mr. Indian Agent Taylor to apply for money to install a new pipeline. The Government was short of money and the Department, then, replied that they thought that the Church authorities should pay for this. As you know, the Church authorities would mean the Oblate Fathers and these have not the $6000.00, if I recall the figures, which would be required.

The Department's view appears to be that this is not a Government school but Oblate buildings used as such. Might it not be urged that this is true and that the Oblate Fathers, besides supplying men to civilize the Indians, have, without charge, put these buildings and spacious grounds at the disposal of the Department for the education and the physical and moral welfare of the Government's wards and have thus saved the government from sinking $250.000.00 in buildings?

Would you please approach the Department and ask that, in view of the children's staying here until July 21st, permission be granted to install a pipeline immediately and that they put a competent man in charge? I would suggest that the digging and whatever other work possible be done by the Indians. Many of them have asked me for work. This would cut down on relief.

The Department most likely has Mr. Warren's report, i.e., I think, took a straighter and shorter line from Yellow Lake to the reservoir. That would cut down on the pipe required and on the digging unless, for the latter, by the time we receive a reply we have dug up most of the pipe—which is 4' down.

I do not think that I have over-stated the case. Either the Department or we will have to spend the money, unless we can remedy the trouble or close the school. Of course, we could hire a couple of men and have them haul water from the creek but you will realize what that would mean. Moreover, neither the...

Department nor we would like to put ourselves in such a position that, in the event of a fire and of children burned, the Press would be able to tell the country that, for the sake of $6000.00, the Department and the Oblates had sacrificed these children.

I am aware that the fire protection here, even with a new pipeline, is inadequate but the Press might miss this but would not overlook our having no water piped to the buildings.

Shortly before I came here, the Dept had twenty-five thousand dollars appropriated for a new water system for us but, at the last moment, the man who had water rights on the source refused to cede his rights and the thing fell through. I was able to help that man, later on, and he willingly agreed to cede his water rights. I informed the Indian Agent immediately but the Department no longer had the money.

The water in Yellow Lake has been examined and found unfit for drinking purposes unless boiled. I have made a point of drinking plenty of it daily, as have others, and have felt no evil effects although I have done it for more than six years. In the really hot weather, the smell and taste are bad but we have a small spring nearby where we can and do get drinking water.

We will keep looking for the trouble. If there are any results, I will telegraph, but after a week's work at the problem I am not at all optimistic.

Respectfully yours,

P.S. Mr. Indian Agent Taylor was asked to come here today to study the situation but was unable. There are serious objections to beginning the holiday before July 21st. Sept. 18th is the earliest we can get the children back and some of them will not be able to be here on that date.

MEMORANDUM:

The Deputy Minister,

I am returning herewith Mr. Jackson's memorandum of October 22nd and also draft recommendation to Council with respect to construction of a new pipeline at the Cariboo Indian Residential School.

I may state that the desirability of providing an adequate water supply for the Cariboo Residential School has been under consideration by the Department for a number of years. The matter was thoroughly investigated by Mr. W. C. Warren, of the Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau, who furnished the Department with a report on August 21st, 1935. Mr. Warren in that report estimated that it would cost approximately $11,065 to provide the residential school with an adequate supply of water for domestic purposes and that it would cost at least $20,220 to provide a supply of water sufficient for domestic purposes and fire protection.

In view of the fact that the financial resources at our disposal at that time were limited, it was decided to make a further investigation with the object of determining if a water supply could be provided at a reduced cost to the Department and the church authorities. Mr. V. Leek, Assistant Director of the Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau, in a letter to the Department dated September 4th, 1935, expressed the view that a temporary supply of water, that might be sufficient for a number of years, could be obtained by the construction of a pipeline from a spring comparatively near the school, and he estimated the cost of this construction at approximately $3,000.

A number of memoranda have been sent forward to the Minister's
the Minister's office with respect to this project and the best ways and means of proceeding with the construction.

May I refer particularly to a memorandum dated July 8, 1937, addressed to you and signed by Mr. T. R. L. MacInnes, Acting Director, in which Mr. MacInnes asked for your concurrence for the payment of a grant of $2,000 toward the cost of this work. This memorandum was approved by you and later returned to this branch. The officials, having obtained your approval for this expenditure, wired H. E. Taylor, Indian Agent, Williams Lake, B. C., on July 15, 1937, authorizing him to inform the Principal of the school that he (the Principal) could proceed with the work. This grant was made on the understanding that the church authorities would contribute at least $2,000 in the purchase of supplies and in making provision for labour costs.

We are now in receipt of accounts from the Pacific Coast Pipe Company, Limited, the firm from whom the pipeline supplies were purchased, asking for settlement of the account.

The Cariboo Residential School is the property of the church authorities, although certain improvements, including the construction of a barn at the school, have been undertaken and paid for by the Government from time to time. The last Auditor's report, signed by Mr. Wey, indicates that the cost per pupil per day at this school amounts to 46.7¢ and that the per capita grants paid last year by the Government amounted to 43.6¢. It would appear from this report that the Principal of this school has in recent years been borrowing money from the Oblate Order but has succeeded in reducing this loan until at that date it amounted to only $365.01. It is only fair to point out, however, that the Oblate Order did not at any time during the life of the loan impose any interest charges.

I am of the opinion that, in view of all the circumstances, a division of the costs necessary to provide the water supply necessary is fair and reasonable. Requests for fire fighting apparatus or for an adequate water
supply have always been given very sympathetic consideration by the Government. Repairs have been undertaken at church-owned schools when the appropriations at our disposal enabled us to undertake such repairs when such were considered necessary and urgent. Suggestions have been made from time to time that the per capita grant to church-owned schools might be increased and the church authorities requested to maintain their own buildings. However, no definite decision has been reached in this matter.

Director.
Memorandum

Dear Mr. Taylor:

As you are aware, the Dept. of Indian Affairs surprised me by granting $1200.00 for the finishing of the laundry, for painting and for repairs. As it was specified that some painting be done (and this was really needed), I bought and used $277.08 worth of paint. It was only after this paint had been bought that our domestic supply pipeline broke down. In response to my appeal for help, the Dept. replied that I should use the $1200.00 already granted and that, if I did so, the Department would add another $800.00 to make up $2000.00 for this work. I was to pay the rest. I was able to buy new pipe very much cheaper than had been estimated by the Gentleman sent to examine the situation. By employing exclusively Indian labour, I was perhaps able to cut down on relief to Indians. However, the thing cost me a pretty penny.

As I bought the paint under the impression (not to say by the orders of the Department; it being specified that part of the $1200.00 be for paint) that this would be paid for out of the extraordinary grant, would you please ask the Department if they would refund this money? The reason for which I make this request is that I need about that sum to buy a second set of batteries for our Delco. The Department was good enough to buy us a Delco and one set of batteries. I should have asked for two sets but, to cut down expenses, I asked for one set as our old set was then fairly good. It is now dead and, unless we wish to ruin the remaining set, another must be purchased immediately. I do not think that I have wasted a cent but I cannot pay my bills. For beef, pork, vegetables, salaries and wood (we burn no coal), I owe over $4000.00, for this year, to the Oblate Fathers. The $150.00 advanced on the Sept Grant is spent.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant enclosing voucher covering the cost of the three toilets and septic tank at the Cariboo Indian Residential School. I regret that owing to the fact that our appropriation for the fiscal year 1937-38 is now exhausted it is not possible to pay from that Vote for the cement and freight charges. However, the accounts for these might be submitted and if it is found possible to provide funds in the current year's appropriation payment will be made. Possibly the best way to handle the matter would be for the school to pay these accounts and have them receipted, then, if funds are available, repayment will be made to the Principal.

Dear Sir:

I thank you for your letter of March 25th and for the fire-extinguishers which are to come.

Evidently I misunderstood and was misunderstood. I understood that of the grant of $700.00, $500.00 was to be spent on the laundry and the balance on repairs and improvements. My plan was to use the $200.00 on renewing some stair cases and floors and on paying half the cost of a flume behind the girls' building. This flume is needed as, at present, the girls' basement is often flooded and the walls undermined. I think that the stair cases and floors can wait until next year and that, if all the $700.00 is spent on the laundry and fire-escapes we can build the flume out of the per capita grant especially as the Oblates will bear half the cost. I had no idea that the $200.00 was for fire-escapes. That money, I fear, will not suffice.

I am making out (or, rather, have made out) a list of what is needed to complete the laundry. You will note that plumbing fixtures are almost entirely omitted. That is because we have them on hand, bought out of the money already granted in past years. You will note, also, that no request is made for machinery. I do not want machinery; first, it is costly; secondly, the girls are used to washing by hand and this is excellent training for their future life. It would be hard to go from the school machinery to the home tub but it is easy to go from the school tub to the home tub. I am very pleased to say that, whenever I have chanced to visit a reserve on washday, I have found, with very few exceptions, that the married ex-schoolgirls were busy at their washing. I might add that even the Sisters do their share at the tubs and this is good example for the girls.
ST. JOSEPH'S MISSION
CARIBOO INDIAN SCHOOL STATION P.G.E.
BRITISH COLUMBIA

A week has elapsed since I finished page one. In the meantime, I have made out a list of all material required for the laundry and have sent it to the Indian Agent. He has just called and we have been able to cut down the costs considerably by deciding to use plain shiplap instead of v-joint and by other changes. He had quotations from local firms but these appear quite high for some items. He will get quotes for most of the building material and for the fire escapes from the Coast. I am trying to make arrangements with other people so that, if the material is supplied, we can get a carload between us and reduce the heavy freight costs.

While it does not matter to me who gets the order, I think that I should point out that, after a few experiments, I have found McLennan, McFeely and Prior, Vancouver, give greatest satisfaction in the hardware line. Their prices on fire-escapes might be high and Mr Taylor will write directly to a foundry. Mr C. Anderson, whose mill is near us, will supply lumber, as in the past, at £16.00 per M. That price, lumber delivered, cannot be beaten. It was he who suggested "finishing" the interior in shiplap instead of the more costly v-joint. It will not look so well but it will be just as good and far cheaper. With the £500.00 I had not expected to complete the laundry this year.

You may have noted, in my recent report, that we have done a great deal of building and repair work. I forgot to mention the great improvement made on our water reservoir. It is now far more sanitary.

Mr Indian Agent Taylor confidentially told me that he had suggested to the Department that relief supplies might be bought wholesale at a great saving and although he did not suggest it allowed me to add a word. From what I hear, the Indians are getting a great deal of dried fruit and sugar which they turn into rather powerful home-brew. Whether they buy this or get it as part of their relief, I do not know. If Mr T's suggestion were adopted, they would not get it in their relief rations. Of course, local store-keepers might howl but if one wholesale order were bought and the store-keepers were told, their prices might come down.
Moreover, I do not know whether it is or is not the case—if, to make money, the store-keepers were suggesting to the Indians that they apply for relief, your relief costs would decrease when the profit to the store-keepers was nil. At present, with so vast a territory to cover, your Agent cannot tell what the Indians are being given.

A story: A former Principal told me that years ago, certain store-keepers used periodically to telegraph to the Dept., saying that the local Indians were starving and asking permission to save them from death by giving—or rather selling—food to the poor Indians. Finally, the Dept. telegraphed to this Principal saying that it was reported that the Indians at---- were starving and asking him to investigate. He did not investigate but replied immediately "Indians at---- not starving. Plenty to drink." Whether there is anything in certain suspicions or not, I cannot say. Mr. Taylor's suggestion, if carried out, might show you.

I am pleased to say that the toilets for the boys' x*x*x*x have come. It will be a great improvement and far more sanitary. Our plumber quoted on the toilets and some pipe only, neglecting to mention tiles from the septic tank. I have informed the Indian Agent. The tile, of course, is necessary.

You have, no doubt, heard of Archbishop Duke's Indian exhibition to be held in Vancouver. We expect to send in some really good beadwork and buckskin work. The local Indians do no carving and very little basket work. As for the prizes, they mean nothing to me after what I saw in Kamloops.

With sincere wishes for a happy Easter,

Yours very truly,

Gentlemen:

Your letter of Feb. 10th, concerning the means to be taken to prevent fires in Indian schools, came while I was away and was left for me to answer.

Your instructions will be carried out as they have been carried out in the past.

We have about 25 fire extinguishers at strategic places and that number might be sufficient. However, as our School consists of four units, not including the "usual" training shop, "warehouse," etc., and as the buildings are frame constructions and, also, as we have no water pressure against fire, it would be in the interests of the safety of the pupils to have even a dozen more fire extinguishers and two larger extinguishers on wheels.

Last year, in order that we might install metal fire escapes in place of the present wooden ones, you kindly increased our extraordinary grant from $600.00 to $1200.00. As you are aware, you had later to instruct me to use this money (a good deal of it had already been spent) to install a domestic water pipeline. The result was that the fire-escapes could not be installed. The pipeline, as you and I were aware, cost a great deal more than the money you could spare. As a result, the school owes the Oblate Fathers over $5000.00 for salaries, meat, fuel, etc.

You kindly granted $700.00 this year. All this money will be required for our laundry which we greatly need as the Indian Agent and the Inspector will tell you.

I am pleased to say that the Inspector appeared very satisfied after his recent inspection. The pupils are in good health.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir-

We have your letter of the 12th last requesting a price on four fire escapes. Stair railings 3/16" x 1" x 1½" angle iron with ¼"x1" bars electric welded.

February 24, 1939

Dear Sir:

In connection with the enclosed report on the Cariboo Indian Residential School for the month of February 1938, I beg to advise that a thorough inspection and test of the fire protection apparatus was made.

The general alarm was tested, but the batteries which operate it were found to be weak, and they are being immediately renewed. The children were outside the building from the class rooms within a reasonable time, but apparently the bell in the corridor of the main building is not sufficiently loud to be heard in some of the class rooms when the doors are closed. This is being remedied by the addition of a bell close to the class room doors. There are 36 fire extinguishers placed in position ready for use. Also 19 fire buckets. The emergency exits were inspected and the doors were found to open freely, and were free from snow and ice.

The epidemic of bronchial colds at the school has entirely cleared up, and good progress is being made with weekly treatments for trachoma.

Your obedient servant,

That, as these buildings are Church property, and maintenance or equipment, repairs, etc., constitute a grant, and therefore, the approval of the Administrator in Council is desirable.

Dear Sir:

In your letter of March 11 you requested refills for the fire extinguishers at the Cariboo Indian Residential School. An order was placed with the Pyrene Manufacturing Company last March and it is presumed the refills were supplied to the school. However, the Principal did not submit any account.

This is a Church-owned school and although a certain amount is provided each year for repairs, maintenance and purchase of new equipment, present regulations do not permit our exceeding the amount specifically provided. If the Principal had carried out the instructions which have been issued to all Principals on several occasions to the effect that all accounts must be certified and forwarded to the Department as soon as the goods are received the account would have been paid from the appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41. However, as he did not carry out these instructions it is not possible to pay the account from that fiscal year.

In the current year's appropriation an amount of $300.00 was provided for repairs and improvements at this school. We have already expended approximately $255.00 and there is only $45.00 left. The account of the Pyrene Manufacturing Company which is attached shows the total cost of the refills as $124.30. You should have this account.

Mr. H.E. Taylor,
Indian Agent,
Williams Lake, B.C.
certified by the Principal and you should advise him that the Department will only be able to pay $45.00 of the amount and that he will have to issue a cheque to the Pyrene Manufacturing Company for the balance.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir: Re: voucher 2196, Pyrene Mfg. Co. $124.30

I beg to refer to letters dated November 15th and December 11th last from the Superintendent of Welfare and Training regarding refills for fire extinguishers supplied to the Cariboo Indian School, under purchase order number 6471.

When these refills were sent to the School an account was not sent by the Pyrene Company to this office. Neither was a copy of the purchase order received here. An account went to the school Principal, who apparently assumed that a voucher would be sent from this office. I obtained an account from the school Principal after receiving Mr. Hoey's letters of November 15th, but delayed submitting a voucher pending a letter of explanation which the School Principal advised me that he was writing to Mr. Hoey.

I informed the Principal that only $45.00 was available in Department funds to be applied on this account, but as the letter of December 11th from Mr. Hoey asked that the account be certified and forwarded I am submitting the voucher for the total amount.
